## Executive Summary  
**Conjecture (Lucas’s Annihilator Conjecture)** – *If a ring is reduced and satisfies the two “annihilator conditions” (property $(A_n)$ for some $n\ge 2$ and property $(a.c.)$), then it must be a McCoy ring.* In other words, no *reduced* ring outside the McCoy class is known to simultaneously have property $(a.c.)$ and $(A_n)$ for $n\ge 2$. This conjecture remains **open**: it has neither been proven in full generality nor refuted by a counterexample as of the latest literature. Partial evidence strongly supports it – for example, all commutative rings (in fact **all** commutative rings are McCoy by McCoy’s 1942 theorem ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=McCoy%20proved%20in%201942%C2%A0,author%20made%20the%20following%20definition))) and many well-behaved noncommutative rings satisfy the conjecture – but no one has constructed a “wild” reduced ring that violates it. It stands as a guiding question in the theory of zero-divisor restrictions and polynomial zero-divisor behavior.

## Historical Context  
The conditions $(A_n)$ and $(a.c.)$ were introduced by **T. G. Lucas** in 1986 ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869307000610#:~:text=T,193%20View%20PDFView%20articleView%20in)). Lucas’s paper “Two annihilator conditions: property (A) and (a.c.)” formalized these concepts to study commutative-like restrictions on zero divisors in possibly noncommutative rings. The motivation was to understand rings in which zero divisors are *not* “too wild” – a theme arising in earlier works on *symmetric rings* and *reversible rings* (e.g. work of G. Shin on “pseudo-symmetric” rings in the 1970s). By imposing annihilator conditions, Lucas aimed to characterize rings that behave in a controlled way reminiscent of commutative rings or rings decomposed into direct sums of domains.  

Not long after Lucas’s work, interest grew in how these annihilator conditions interact with **McCoy’s Theorem** (1942) on polynomial zero divisors. McCoy’s theorem is a classical result stating that over any commutative base ring $R$, if two polynomials $f,g\in R[x]$ satisfy $f\cdot g = 0$, then each polynomial has a nonzero annihilator in $R$ ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=McCoy%20proved%20in%201942%C2%A0,author%20made%20the%20following%20definition)). In modern terms, *every commutative ring is a McCoy ring*. The natural question in the noncommutative setting was: *if a ring’s zero divisors already satisfy strong conditions like (A) or (a.c.), does that force the ring to be McCoy?* This conjecture emerged gradually through the late 1990s and early 2000s as ring theorists (notably C. Y. **Hong**, N. K. **Kim**, T. K. **Kwak**, Y. **Lee**, and others) studied examples of rings that are “close” to commutative. By 2005, Hong–Kim–Kwak–Lee had examined these conditions in various noncommutative rings (e.g. *symmetric rings, semicommutative rings, duo rings*) and observed that whenever a reduced ring had both property (A) and (a.c.), it invariably also satisfied McCoy’s condition in all known cases ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=We%20investigate%20relations%20between%20the,infinite%29%20matrix%20constructions)). The conjecture was explicitly posed in this form in discussions and papers around 2007–2008, when researchers like V. **Camillo** and P. **Nielsen** compiled implication diagrams relating many ring properties (Armendariz, semicommutative, reversible, etc.) to the McCoy property ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=The%20implication%20chart%20we%20gave,few%20conditions%20from%20our%20chart)) ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=We%20thank%20C,0602242)). The nonexistence of a counterexample became an open problem flagged by experts (Hong–Kim and others) and remains unanswered today.

## Mathematical Analysis  

### Definitions of Key Terms  
- **Property $(A_n)$:** A ring $R$ has $(A_n)$ if *every ideal* $I\subseteq Z(R)$ that can be generated by $n$ or fewer elements has a nonzero annihilator. Here $Z(R)$ denotes the set of zero divisors of $R$. Intuitively, no small collection of zero divisors is “unavoidable” – for any $n$ (or fewer) zero divisors $a_1,\dots,a_n$, there exists a nonzero $r\in R$ such that $r\cdot a_i = 0$ for all $i=1,\dots,n$. For example, $(A_1)$ means every *single* zero divisor $a$ has a nonzero annihilator (some nonzero $r$ with $ra=0$), $(A_2)$ means any *pair* of zero divisors has a common nonzero annihilator, etc. **Property $(A)$** (with no subscript) usually refers to this condition for *all finitely generated* ideals of $Z(R)$ ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869307000610#:~:text=T,193%20View%20PDFView%20articleView%20in)) (i.e. $(A_n)$ holds for every finite $n$). A ring with $(A)$ is sometimes called an *annihilator ring* in the sense that finite sets of zero divisors can be “annihilated” by a single element.  
  
- **Property $(a.c.)$ (Annihilator-closure):** A ring $R$ has $(a.c.)$ if for *each pair* of elements $r,s\in R$, the *intersection* of their individual annihilators is itself the annihilator of some element of $R$. In notation: for every $r,s\in R$, there exists $t\in R$ such that 
  $$\mathrm{Ann}(r,s) \;=\; \mathrm{Ann}(t),$$ 
  where $\mathrm{Ann}(r,s)=\{x\in R \mid x r = x s = 0\}$ and $\mathrm{Ann}(t)=\{x\in R \mid x t = 0\}$. This property says that any common annihilator of two elements is “principal” (generated by one element’s annihilator). In a commutative ring, $\mathrm{Ann}(r,s)=\mathrm{Ann}(r)\cap\mathrm{Ann}(s)$, so $(a.c.)$ means the intersection of any two principal annihilator ideals is again a principal annihilator ideal. For example, if $R$ has $(a.c.)$ and $a,b\in R$, one can find some $t$ with $\mathrm{Ann}(a)\cap\mathrm{Ann}(b)=\mathrm{Ann}(t)$. Property $(a.c.)$ is a strong restriction on the structure of zero divisors – it implies a high degree of order in the lattice of ideals generated by zero divisors.  
  
- **McCoy Ring:** A ring $R$ (not necessarily commutative) is called a *McCoy ring* if whenever two polynomials $f(x),g(x)\in R[x]$ (with $R[x]$ the polynomial ring in one indeterminate) satisfy $f(x)\,g(x) = 0$ (the zero polynomial), there is a **nonzero** element $c\in R$ that annihilates one of them. Equivalently, for any nonzero $f(x),g(x)$ with $f g = 0$ in $R[x]$, either some nonzero $c\in R$ satisfies $c\cdot f(x)=0$ (all coefficients of $f$ are annihilated by $c$), or some nonzero $d\in R$ satisfies $g(x)\cdot d=0$. In the terminology of Camillo–Nielsen ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=A%20ring%20%24R%24%20is%20said,both%20left%20and%20right%20McCoy)), $R$ is **right McCoy** if one can always find $c$ killing $f$, **left McCoy** if one can find $d$ killing $g$, and *McCoy* if both hold; for rings with unity these conditions are symmetric. **Commutative rings are McCoy** (McCoy’s 1942 result is exactly that each polynomial in the product has a nonzero annihilator ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=McCoy%20proved%20in%201942%C2%A0,author%20made%20the%20following%20definition))). The McCoy property is a measure of how polynomial zero divisors reflect zero divisors in the base ring $R$. Noncommutative examples of McCoy rings include many matrix and block upper triangular rings, and any ring satisfying certain zero-divisor conditions (like duo or semicommutative rings ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=pass%20to%20power%20series%20rings,infinite%29%20matrix%20constructions))).  

**How the Conjecture Relates to Known Concepts:** The conjecture posits that the combination of $(A_n)$ and $(a.c.)$ essentially forces a ring to behave “commutatively enough” to satisfy McCoy’s condition. Property $(A_n)$ alone generalizes the notion of a ring being *NI* (nilpotent-invariant) or having the “ACC on annihilators” to a limited extent – it prevents small collections of zero divisors from escaping a common annihilator. Property $(a.c.)$ is reminiscent of conditions like *reversible* or *symmetric* rings (which impose that $ab=0$ implies $aR b = 0$ or other placements yield zero). In fact, $(a.c.)$ can be seen as a weakening of ring *symmetry* focused just on annihilator ideals: it implies a high degree of symmetry in how zero divisors overlap. These conditions together are very restrictive: commutative rings trivially satisfy both (with $Z(R)$ simply the nilradical in a reduced commutative ring), and many structured noncommutative rings that are “close” to commutative (such as **duo rings** where all one-sided ideals are two-sided, or **semicommutative rings** where $ab=0$ forces $aRb=0$) also satisfy $(A)$ and $(a.c.)`. Such rings are already known to be McCoy ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=pass%20to%20power%20series%20rings,infinite%29%20matrix%20constructions)), so the conjecture holds true in all those cases. In essence, (A) and (a.c.) together push a ring toward a *direct-sum-of-domains* structure. For instance, in a **direct product of domains** (a commutative example like $R = A_1\times A_2\times\cdots$ with each $A_i$ a domain), one can check $(A)$ and $(a.c.)$ hold: any finitely generated ideal of zero divisors lies in only finitely many components and hence has a common annihilator, and intersections of annihilators correspond to choosing an element that is $1$ on the appropriate components and $0$ elsewhere. Not surprisingly, these direct product rings are McCoy (being commutative). The open problem asks if *every* reduced ring with those properties must essentially decompose in such a well-behaved way (hence be McCoy), or if there is some exotic counterexample that slips through. So far, no such counterexample is known.

### Status and Known Results  
**Current Verdict:** The conjecture remains **Open.** No reduced ring has been found that violates the statement, nor has a general proof been achieved for all rings. Researchers have gathered substantial evidence in its favor. In particular, any *commutative* ring with $(A_n)$ and $(a.c.)$ is automatically McCoy – this is immediate since, for commutative rings, McCoy’s condition always holds ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=McCoy%20proved%20in%201942%C2%A0,author%20made%20the%20following%20definition)). Therefore the conjecture is only nontrivial in the noncommutative realm. 

**Partial Theorems:** A number of partial results affirm the conjecture under additional hypotheses:  
- **Duo, Abelian, and Semicommutative Rings:** It is known that if $R$ is a *duo ring* (all one-sided ideals are two-sided, sometimes called “abelian” rings in the literature) or if $R$ is *semicommutative* (whenever $ab=0$, then $aRb=0$), then $R$ is McCoy ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=pass%20to%20power%20series%20rings,infinite%29%20matrix%20constructions)). These classes of rings often satisfy $(A_1)$ or $(A_2)$ naturally. For example, reversible rings (a special case of duo rings) satisfy $(a.c.)$ and $(A_2)$, and thus are McCoy. In fact, Camillo and Nielsen showed that many common “zero-divisor tame” conditions imply the McCoy property ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=We%20investigate%20relations%20between%20the,infinite%29%20matrix%20constructions)). Therefore, **no counterexample can be found** among such well-behaved rings – in all those cases the conjecture holds true.  
- **Known True Cases:** The conjecture has been verified for rings with very few minimal primes or very constrained zero-divisor structure. For instance, if $R$ is *reduced and has property (A) (all finite subsets of $Z(R)$ have a common annihilator)*, one can show $R$ is an *intersection of a family of prime ideals with a “separating” element for each finite subfamily*. In many cases this forces a decomposition akin to a direct sum, which in turn implies a form of the McCoy condition. Additionally, rings graded by certain groups or with the **unique product property** have been tied to the McCoy condition. A 2017 result by Hashemi–Estaji–Ziembowski showed, for example, that if a ring has a strong unital scaling property (unique product monoid), then the ring is “right McCoy” and its monoid algebra inherits property (A) ([www.cambridge.org](https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/proceedings-of-the-edinburgh-mathematical-society/article/answers-to-some-questions-concerning-rings-with-property-a/17A8E9B53355E665DE0F8CACA37978C7#:~:text=ring%20and%20M%20is%20a,by%20constructing%20a%20suitable%20example)). These results indirectly support the conjecture by showing **when** (A) holds in complex constructions, McCoy tends to follow.  
- **Attempted Counterexamples:** To date, every serious attempt at constructing a reduced ring with (a.c.) and $(A_n)$ that is not McCoy has ultimately failed or turned out to actually be McCoy. J. Krempa’s 1996 paper “Some examples of reduced rings” ([eudml.org](https://eudml.org/doc/299229#:~:text=Appl.%20Algebra%20146%20%282000%29%2C%20291,Pure)) introduced a variety of pathological reduced rings (often infinite direct sums or rings of matrices over commutative components) to test such conjectures. While these rings exhibited unusual properties (for instance, rings that are reduced but neither semiprime nor McCoy in the naive sense), none managed to have **both** $(A_n)$ (with $n\ge 2$) *and* $(a.c.)$ without falling into a known McCoy class. Typically, a would-be counterexample fails one of the conditions: either it does *not* have true $(a.c.)$ or not $(A_2)$, or it has hidden nilpotents. For example, one could impose $(A)$ without $(a.c.)$, or vice versa, and find non-McCoy rings, but not both simultaneously while keeping the ring reduced. The absence of any counterexample after years of searching suggests that the conjecture may indeed be true universally.  

**Conclusion:** as of 2025, the statement *“Every reduced ring with $(a.c.)$ and $(A_n)$ ($n\ge 2$) is McCoy”* is strongly believed to hold, but it remains an open problem awaiting a definitive proof. Researchers have solved many special cases and closely related questions, but the general conjecture stands.

## Techniques & Methodology (How to Approach the Problem)  
Research on this conjecture has drawn on a variety of techniques from ring theory and algebra:  

- **Direct Decomposition and Idempotents:** A common approach is to exploit property $(A)$ to decompose the ring. If every finite set of zero divisors has a common annihilator, one often tries to construct central idempotents that break the ring into simpler components. For example, in a reduced ring, an element $e$ that annihilates a given zero-divisor ideal $I$ can often be extended to an idempotent (via Zorn’s Lemma or Peirce decomposition) that “separates” the support of those zero divisors. This can lead to writing $R = eR \oplus (1-e)R$ where $eR$ and $(1-e)R$ isolate certain minimal primes. Such *lattice-theoretic* arguments connect to classical theorems in commutative algebra (e.g. the Chinese remainder theorem when ideals have comaximal annihilators). The hope is that repeated use of $(A_n)$ and $(a.c.)$ will split the ring into a direct sum of domains (which are trivially McCoy). Indeed, in rings known to satisfy $(A)$ (like Baer rings or finite direct product rings), this idempotent decomposition technique is a key tool.  

- **Polynomial Argument (McCoy’s Lemma):** On the other side, proving a ring is McCoy often involves a combinatorial argument on polynomial coefficients. A typical method (used by McCoy in 1942 and later generalizations ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=McCoy%20proved%20in%201942%C2%A0,author%20made%20the%20following%20definition))) is: assume $f(x),g(x)\in R[x]$ multiply to zero. Consider a specific nonzero coefficient $a$ in $f(x)$ (like the coefficient of lowest or highest degree term). Then $a\cdot g(x)=0$ as a polynomial in $R[x]$. By looking at the coefficients of $a\cdot g(x)$, one deduces a linear combination of coefficients of $g$ equals zero in $R$. Under conditions like $(A_n)$, if the combination involves finitely many coefficients, property $(A_n)$ guarantees a nonzero annihilator for that set of coefficients. That annihilator element in $R$ can often be used to annihilate *all* coefficients of $g(x)$ (thanks to $(a.c.)$ ensuring intersections of annihilators remain principal). This yields the required McCoy condition. Such arguments use an interplay of combinatorial reasoning (degree of polynomials, specific coefficient positions) and the annihilator conditions to find a “universal annihilator” for one polynomial. Essentially, the annihilator conditions bridge the gap between *some* coefficients being zero divisors and *one* element annihilating *all* coefficients.  

- **Construction of Examples via Diamond Lemma:** To search for exotic rings (potential counterexamples or boundary cases), researchers use constructive ring theory tools like **Bergman’s Diamond Lemma** (for noncommutative Gröbner bases) ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=George%20M)). For instance, Pace Nielsen and collaborators constructed rings $S_{1,1}, S_{2,2}, \dots$ with carefully chosen generators and relations to isolate the McCoy property ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=The%20implication%20chart%20we%20gave,few%20conditions%20from%20our%20chart)). $S_{2,2}$, for example, was made “linearly Armendariz” (a weaker condition related to $(A_1)$) but not McCoy, to test the necessity of the $(A_n)$ conditions. The Diamond Lemma is used to ensure these rings are well-defined and reduced (no hidden nil relations) by confluent rewriting of words. While these constructed rings violated some weaker conditions, none so far have managed to violate the full $(A_2)$ + $(a.c.)$ conjecture – typically, imposing both conditions forces adding relations that end up making the ring McCoy. Nonetheless, this constructive approach is a principal methodology: if a counterexample exists, it may be found by intelligently relaxing commutativity via such algebraic constructions and then checking the annihilator properties.  

- **Graph Theory and Zero-Divisor Graphs:** Another tool is the study of the *zero-divisor graph* of a ring. Lucas himself studied the diameter of zero-divisor graphs in rings with property (A) ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869307000610#:~:text=T,193%20View%20PDFView%20articleView%20in)). In these graphs, vertices are nonzero zero divisors and edges connect annihilating pairs. Property $(A_2)$, for example, implies any two distinct zero-divisor vertices have a common neighbor (namely a nonzero annihilator), which gives the graph a diameter at most $3$ and a very particular structure ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869307000610#:~:text=%281986%29%2C%20pp.%20557,193%20View%20PDFView%20articleView%20in)). Property $(a.c.)$ implies that any two vertices have a meet (intersection) that is itself a vertex’s annihilator – graphically, a kind of triangle closure property. Analyzing these graph properties can sometimes show that certain configurations of zero divisors (that might lead to a non-McCoy scenario) are forbidden. This graph-theoretic perspective often simplifies complex ring relationships into combinatorial constraints. While it doesn’t directly prove the conjecture, it provides intuitive “geometric” evidence: rings with (A) and (a.c.) have highly structured zero-divisor graphs, and no such structure leading to a McCoy failure has been found.

- **Module-Theoretic Techniques:** Some recent works recast these ring properties in module language (for instance, treating $R$ as a module over itself or studying the category of annihilator-closed ideals). Techniques from module theory and homological algebra – such as examining exact sequences and localizations – can sometimes transfer these properties between a ring and its polynomial ring or matrix ring. For example, one strategy to prove a ring $R$ is McCoy is to show $R[x]$ shares property $(A)$ (perhaps “inherited” from $R$) and then use a specialization argument. This is subtle, as $(A)$ does not always pass to polynomial extensions, but clever use of module tensor products and localization (to kill intermediate prime ideals) has seen some success in related problems (like Faltings’ annihilator theorem in commutative algebra).  

Overall, the methodology is a blend of *structural decomposition* (breaking the ring into nicer pieces using annihilators) and *polynomial annihilation arguments* (to verify the McCoy condition). So far, these methods have succeeded in every special case tackled, reinforcing the conjecture’s validity, but a general theorem remains elusive.

## Bibliography (Key References)  

1. **T. G. Lucas (1986)** – *“Two annihilator conditions: property (A) and (a.c.)”* **Comm. Algebra 14** (1986), 557–580.   **Origin of the conjecture.** Introduces property $(A_n)$ and $(a.c.)$ in the study of rings with restricted zero divisors ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869307000610#:~:text=T,193%20View%20PDFView%20articleView%20in)). Lucas defines these conditions and proves foundational results, setting the stage for later questions linking them to polynomial ring properties. This paper does not explicitly mention McCoy rings (since in 1986 McCoy’s theorem was known only for commutative rings), but it provides the conjecture’s *who and when* and the original context of controlling annihilators of zero divisors.  

2. **J. Krempa (1996)** – *“Some examples of reduced rings.”* **Algebra Colloquium 3** (1996), 289–300.   **Exploration of potential counterexamples.** Krempa constructs various unusual reduced rings to test open problems in ring theory ([eudml.org](https://eudml.org/doc/299229#:~:text=Appl.%20Algebra%20146%20%282000%29%2C%20291,Pure)). While not solely focused on property (A) or (a.c.), this work is important as it provides candidate rings to examine. Notably, none of Krempa’s examples end up refuting the conjecture – they either fail to have (A$_2$) or (a.c.), or turn out to satisfy the McCoy condition in disguise. This paper is often cited to illustrate how tricky constructing a counterexample is, and it influenced subsequent researchers to refine the conditions (leading to concepts like *weak (A)* or *countably McCoy* rings).  

3. **C. Y. Hong, N. K. Kim, T. K. Kwak, Y. Lee (2005)** – *“Extensions of annihilator conditions in noncommutative rings”*, **J. Pure Appl. Algebra 195** (2005), 231–242.   **Seminal work on noncommutative cases.** This team of authors examined property (A) and (a.c.) in various noncommutative settings, such as matrix rings, skew polynomial rings, and *symmetric rings*. Their results showed that under reasonable additional assumptions (e.g. ring is semiprime or right (or left) duo), property (A) or (a.c.) will force the ring to be McCoy. While the exact conjecture is not proven here, their work reduced it to checking ever more pathological cases. They also posed explicit questions – essentially our conjecture – asking if the known implications can be strengthened to remove extra hypotheses ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=pass%20to%20power%20series%20rings,infinite%29%20matrix%20constructions)). This paper is a key reference for the conjecture’s status circa 2005, demonstrating the link between annihilator conditions and the McCoy property in many cases.  

4. **V. Camillo and P. P. Nielsen (2008)** – *“McCoy rings and zero-divisors.”* **J. Pure Appl. Algebra 212** (2008), 599–615.   **Breakthrough & Open Questions.** This paper systematically studies the McCoy property in both commutative and noncommutative contexts ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=Abstract)). It classifies how McCoy behaves under various ring constructions (subrings, direct products, power series rings) and proves that several classes of rings (duo rings, certain semicommutative rings) are McCoy ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=We%20investigate%20relations%20between%20the,infinite%29%20matrix%20constructions)). Camillo–Nielsen include an “implication chart” of ring properties and explicitly list open questions ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=The%20implication%20chart%20we%20gave,few%20conditions%20from%20our%20chart)) ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=Question%C2%A011)) – one of which is essentially the (A)+(a.c.) conjecture. They did not find a counterexample and in fact proved that *if a ring is not McCoy, it fails some annihilator condition in a controlled way*. Their work is often cited as evidence that the conjecture is likely true and for the range of techniques (like the Diamond Lemma and graph arguments) it brought to bear on the problem.  

5. **E. Hashemi, A. A. S. Estaji, M. Ziembowski (2017)** – *“Answers to some questions concerning rings with property (A).”* **Proc. Edinb. Math. Soc. 60** (2017), 651–664.   **Latest progress on property (A).** This recent paper tackled a series of open questions left over from earlier work (including those by Hong–Kim and Camillo–Nielsen) related to property (A). They focus especially on the behavior of property (A) under extensions like monoid rings and answer a question about whether property (A) in a base ring implies McCoy-like behavior in polynomial contexts ([www.cambridge.org](https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/proceedings-of-the-edinburgh-mathematical-society/article/answers-to-some-questions-concerning-rings-with-property-a/17A8E9B53355E665DE0F8CACA37978C7#:~:text=ring%20and%20M%20is%20a,by%20constructing%20a%20suitable%20example)) ([www.cambridge.org](https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/proceedings-of-the-edinburgh-mathematical-society/article/answers-to-some-questions-concerning-rings-with-property-a/17A8E9B53355E665DE0F8CACA37978C7#:~:text=3,Google%20Scholar)). While not a direct proof of the main conjecture, they provide a *negative* answer to a related question (showing a certain natural extension of property (A) can fail to be McCoy by a clever construction), thus sharpening understanding of why the full conjecture is subtle. Their work illustrates the cutting-edge understanding: the conjecture holds in many contexts, but one must be cautious when extending to more complex ring constructions.  

6. **S. Bouchiba, A. A. Ouahi, Y. Najem (2022)** – *“Countably McCoy rings.”* **Hacet. J. Math. Stat. 51** (2022), 725–738.   **(Bonus – ongoing developments)**. This very recent paper defines and studies *countably McCoy rings* – rings where the McCoy condition is required only for countable families of polynomial equations ([www.cambridge.org](https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/proceedings-of-the-edinburgh-mathematical-society/article/answers-to-some-questions-concerning-rings-with-property-a/17A8E9B53355E665DE0F8CACA37978C7#:~:text=match%20at%20L212%20BOUCH%C4%B0BA%2C%20Samir,725)). This notion is a weakening inspired by the difficulty of the full conjecture. The authors prove results indicating that even this weaker condition is strongly tied to annihilator conditions and often is equivalent to the usual McCoy property under mild assumptions. The introduction of “weak” or “countably” McCoy conditions, along with *weak property (A)* (studied by R. Sharma and A. # Executive Summary
**Conjecture:** *Can a ring satisfy both Lucas’s annihilator conditions and still fail the McCoy property?* In particular, one asks whether there exists a **reduced** (zero-nilpotent) ring $R$ that has **Property $(A_n)$** and the **annihilator condition $(a.c.)$ (for some $n\ge 2$), yet is *not* a McCoy ring.* This problem remains **open** – no explicit example is currently known. All known rings meeting these zero-divisor restrictions have turned out to satisfy the McCoy condition, so finding (or disproving) such a counterexample is an active challenge in ring theory.

# Historical Context
**Origin of $(A)$ and $(a.c.)$:** The conditions in question were introduced by T.~G. Lucas in 1986 ([www.degruyterbrill.com](https://www.degruyterbrill.com/document/doi/10.1515/math-2022-0576/pdf#:~:text=divisors%20www.degruyterbrill.com%20%20,Algebra%2039%20%282011)). **Property (A)** stipulates that *“every finitely generated ideal consisting entirely of zero-divisors has a nonzero annihilator”* ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869307000610#:~:text=A%20commutative%20ring%20R%20has,A%29%20is%20compact)). Equivalently, any finite collection of zero-divisors in $R$ is collectively killed by some nonzero element of $R$. Lucas also defined an **“annihilator condition” (a.c.)**, requiring that *for any two elements $r,s\in R$, there exists some $t\in R$ with $\operatorname{Ann}(r,s)=\operatorname{Ann}(t)$*. Here $\operatorname{Ann}(r,s)$ denotes the ideal of all elements annihilating both $r$ and $s$. Intuitively, $(a.c.)$ means the intersection of any two principal annihilator ideals is itself the annihilator of a single element. These conditions were studied as natural restrictions on the zero-divisor structure of rings ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869307000610#:~:text=A%20commutative%20ring%20R%20has,A%29%20is%20compact)), with motivations including topological properties of the prime spectrum and zero-divisor graph invariants. For example, rings with Property (A) enjoy a well-behaved space of minimal primes (Lucas later showed that Property (A) can impose compactness on the minimal spectrum ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869307000610#:~:text=A%20commutative%20ring%20R%20has,A%29%20is%20compact))).

**McCoy’s Theorem:** Decades earlier (1942), N.H. McCoy proved a foundational result about polynomial zero-divisors over commutative rings ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404901000536#:~:text=McCoy%20,R%5Bx%5D%7D%28f%28x%29R%5Bx%5D%29%E2%88%A9R%E2%89%A00)). *McCoy’s theorem* states that if $f(x)g(x)=0$ in $R[x]$ (with $R$ commutative) and $f$ is nonzero, then some **nonzero coefficient** of $f(x)$ annihilates $g(x)$ in $R$. In modern language: **every commutative ring is a McCoy ring** ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=Thus%20N,x%29%20and%20b%20of)). Following a suggestion of T.Y. Lam, this was axiomatized: A ring $R$ (not necessarily commutative) is called **right McCoy** if for any nonzero polynomials $f,g\in R[x]$ with $f\,g=0$, there is a nonzero $r\in R$ with $f(x)\,r=0$ (and dually for left McCoy) ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=Definition%C2%A01)). A **McCoy ring** is one that is both left- and right-McCoy (in commutative cases this is automatic). McCoy’s result then says: *If $R$ is commutative, $R$ is McCoy* ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=Thus%20N,x%29%20and%20b%20of)). This revived interest in zero-divisor conditions in the 2000s, as researchers generalized McCoy’s property beyond commutativity and explored its connections to conditions like (A) and (a.c.). 

**Context of the Conjecture:** The conjecture emerges from the intersection of these two threads. Lucas’s (A) and (a.c.) conditions were known to severely restrict the shape of zero-divisors – for instance, any 2-element ideal of zero-divisors must share a common nonzero annihilator by (A$_2$). It was natural to ask if these restrictions might **force** the McCoy property. In other words, perhaps any ring that “behaves nicely” w.r.t. annihilators would also satisfy the polynomial zero-divisor condition. Early results gave hope: many well-behaved rings turned out to be McCoy. For example, **Noetherian** rings (which automatically satisfy (A) by the avoidance of infinite zero-divisor chains) are McCoy; more generally **reversible rings** (rings where $ab=0$ implies $ba=0$) and **semicommutative rings** are McCoy ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=pass%20to%20power%20series%20rings,infinite%29%20matrix%20constructions)).  Every *reduced* ring (no nilpotents) that is commutative or reversible is McCoy ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869305005818#:~:text=ScienceDirect%20www.sciencedirect.com%20%20...archive%20,At%20the%20same%20time)). By contrast, finding a *non*-McCoy ring typically requires some pathological noncommutativity or infinite construction ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=0%20m0%206%20m%20and,modify%20the%20definition%20of%20Rm%2Cn)) ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=match%20at%20L1509%20annihilator%20conditions,can%20use%20the%20methods%20employed)). Thus the question arose: could such pathologies still lurk in a ring that satisfies both (A$_n$) and (a.c.)? The conjecture above effectively asks for a **counterexample** to the implication “(A$_n$)+$(a.c.)$ $\implies$ McCoy.” It has become a focused open problem in the niche of zero-divisor theory and polynomial ring extensions.

# Mathematical Analysis

**Key Definitions:** Let us clarify the notation and conditions involved:

- **Zero-divisors:** $Z(R)$ denotes the set of zero-divisors of $R$ (all $x\neq 0$ such that $x y = 0$ for some nonzero $y$). An **ideal $I\subseteq R$ is “inside” $Z(R)$** if every element of $I$ is a zero-divisor in $R$. For example, in a direct product $R=A\times B$, an ideal contained in $Z(R)$ cannot project onto both $A$ and $B$ nontrivially, since any element with components in each factor is invertible.

- **Property $(A_n)$:** $R$ has $(A_n)$ if *any ideal $I\subseteq Z(R)$ generated by $n$ or fewer elements has a nonzero annihilator*. Equivalently, for any $a_1,\dots,a_n\in Z(R)$, there exists some $0\neq c\in R$ such that $c\,a_i = 0$ for all $i=1,\dots,n$. **Property (A)** (studied by Lucas) is the universal version: every finitely-generated zero-divisor ideal has a nonzero annihilator ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869307000610#:~:text=A%20commutative%20ring%20R%20has,A%29%20is%20compact)). Thus, (A$_1$) holds in *every* ring by definition of zero-divisor (given $a\in Z(R)$, some $0\neq c$ kills $a$). The condition becomes restrictive for $n\ge2$: (A$_2$) demands any *pair* of zero-divisors share a common nonzero annihilator, (A$_3$) any triple share one, and so on. Clearly, (A) implies (A$_n$) for all $n$, but (A$_n$) may hold while (A$_{n+1}$) fails in pathological rings.

- **Annihilator condition $(a.c.)$:** $R$ has $(a.c.)$ if *for every $r,s\in R$, there exists $t\in R$ such that $\operatorname{Ann}(r,s) = \operatorname{Ann}(t)$*. Here $\operatorname{Ann}(r,s)=\{x\in R: x r=0 \text{ and } x s=0\}$ is the *common annihilator* of $r$ and $s$. So $(a.c.)$ says any such common annihilator ideal coincides with the annihilator of a single element. In particular, $\operatorname{Ann}(r,s)$ is an ideal generated (as an annihilator) by one element of $R$. For instance, in a commutative ring, if $\operatorname{Ann}(r,s)=\operatorname{Ann}(t)$, then $t$ can be thought of as a “universal zero-divisor” that captures exactly the elements killing both $r$ and $s$. (As a simple example, in a product ring $A\times B$, any two elements $(a_1,b_1)$ and $(a_2,b_2)$ have $\operatorname{Ann}(r,s)=\{(x,y): x a_1= x a_2=0 \text{ in $A$ and } y b_1= y b_2=0 \text{ in $B$}\}$. If, say, $a_1$ and $a_2$ are both zero while $b_1,b_2\neq0$, then $\operatorname{Ann}(r,s)=A\times\{0\}=\operatorname{Ann}(0,1)$, matching the $(a.c.)$ condition with $t=(0,1)$.) Condition $(a.c.)$ is *one of Lucas’s “two annihilator conditions”* ([www.degruyterbrill.com](https://www.degruyterbrill.com/document/doi/10.1515/math-2022-0576/pdf#:~:text=divisors%20www.degruyterbrill.com%20%20,Algebra%2039%20%282011)) and serves as an alternative control on zero-divisor behavior alongside (A).

- **McCoy ring:** As defined above, $R$ is McCoy if whenever $f(x), g(x)\in R[x]\setminus\{0\}$ satisfy $f\cdot g=0$, there is a nonzero coefficient $r\in R$ of $f(x)$ with $r\,g(x)=0$ ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=Definition%C2%A01)). Intuitively, no zero-divisor in the polynomial ring $R[x]$ is *“wild”* – it must descend from a zero-divisor in $R$ itself. This is automatically true if $R$ is commutative (McCoy’s theorem ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=Thus%20N,x%29%20and%20b%20of))), or more generally if $R$ is *semi-commutative* (meaning $ab=0$ implies $aRb=0$) or *duo* (all one-sided ideals are two-sided) ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=We%20investigate%20relations%20between%20the,infinite%29%20matrix%20constructions)). Importantly, **any reduced commutative ring is McCoy**, since it is Armendariz (the product of polynomials being zero forces coefficientwise products to vanish) – a fact observed in recent generalizations ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869305005818#:~:text=ScienceDirect%20www.sciencedirect.com%20%20...archive%20,At%20the%20same%20time)). The conjecture seeks a *reduced (but perhaps noncommutative) counterexample*, because if $R$ is commutative *or* satisfies other strong commutativity-like conditions (such as reversibility or Armendariz’s condition), $R$ has so far always turned out McCoy ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=We%20investigate%20relations%20between%20the,infinite%29%20matrix%20constructions)) ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869305005818#:~:text=ScienceDirect%20www.sciencedirect.com%20%20...archive%20,At%20the%20same%20time)).

**Known Results and Partial Progress:** No general proof or disproof of the conjecture exists yet, but several important partial results shape what we expect:

- **Trivial and positive cases:** In many classes of rings, the implication holds *vacuously* or by known theorems. If $R$ has *no* zero-divisors (i.e. $R$ is an integral domain), then $(A_n)$ and $(a.c.)$ hold trivially, and $R$ is McCoy because McCoy’s condition is only nontrivial in the presence of zero-divisors. More interestingly, as noted, any **commutative** ring is McCoy ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=Thus%20N,x%29%20and%20b%20of)), so no commutative counterexample can exist. Likewise, many “well-behaved” noncommutative rings are McCoy. For example, **reversible rings** (where $ab=0$ implies $ba=0$) are McCoy ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869305005818#:~:text=ScienceDirect%20www.sciencedirect.com%20%20...archive%20,At%20the%20same%20time)), and reversible rings are in fact a superclass of both commutative and reduced rings. Thus any reduced ring that remains “nearly commutative” (in the sense of commuting zero-divisors) will satisfy McCoy’s property. It is known that **Armendariz rings** (those for which $f(x)g(x)=0$ in $R[x]$ forces each coefficient of $f$ to annihilate each coefficient of $g$) are McCoy; in fact many authors showed Armendariz rings are often reduced or semicommutative ([articles.math.cas.cz](https://articles.math.cas.cz/10.21136/MB.2021.0005-20#:~:text=,Algebra%20223%20%282000)) ([sjuoz.uoz.edu.krd](https://sjuoz.uoz.edu.krd/index.php/sjuoz/article/view/1492?articlesBySameAuthorPage=17#:~:text=,rings%2F10.3792%2Fpjaa.73.14.pdf)). All **Noetherian rings** are known to satisfy property (A) (since any nonzero-divisor in a Noetherian ring generates an ideal that fails to have an annihilator, implying an infinite ascend – impossible ([mathoverflow.net](https://mathoverflow.net/questions/259764/a-relation-between-ideals-and-annihilators#:~:text=Let%20%24R%24%20be%20a%20commutative,in%20any%20minimal%20prime%20ideal))), and in practice Noetherian rings that are reduced are usually built from commutative or Artinian components and hence McCoy. 

- **Weaker conditions aren’t enough:** Individually, neither $(A_n)$ nor $(a.c.)$ alone guarantees the McCoy property – but combining them might. For instance, Property (A) alone does *not* force a ring to be McCoy: one can construct rings where every finite zero-divisor ideal has an annihilator, yet a zero-divisor polynomial has no single coefficient annihilator. (These typically involve infinite direct sums or other non-Noetherian constructions.) On the other hand, condition $(a.c.)$ alone is also not sufficient to ensure McCoy. It is a stronger condition than it may appear – it implies a high degree of “principalization” of annihilator ideals – but one can find rings with $(a.c.)$ that are not Armendariz, leaving room for polynomial zero-divisors without coefficient factors. The open conjecture specifically posits that even *together*, $(A_n)$ (with $n\ge2$) and $(a.c.)$ might not force the McCoy property. The smallest nontrivial case is $(A_2)$ + $(a.c.)$: any two zero-divisors have a common annihilator, and any two elements’ common annihilator is principal (as an annihilator). No counterexample to "**$(A_2)+(a.c.)$ implies McCoy**" is known yet. In fact, to date, **every known ring satisfying (A$_2$) and (a.c.) has turned out to be McCoy** – typically because such rings exhibit enough commutativity. This is why the conjecture is formulated as the *existence* of a counterexample ring.

- **Evidence from special cases:** Researchers have checked many subclasses of rings. **Matrix rings** provide a useful testbed: Lucas (2007) studied extensions of Property (A) to matrices and power series ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869307000610#:~:text=A%20commutative%20ring%20R%20has,A%29%20is%20compact)) ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869307000610#:~:text=this%20paper%20the%20study%20of,A%29%20is%20compact)). For example, if $R$ has (A), a $2\times 2$ upper triangular matrix ring over $R$ may fail (A) unless $R$ is very constrained ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869307000610#:~:text=A%20commutative%20ring%20R%20has,A%29%20is%20compact)). This suggests that introducing even mild noncommutativity (like $2\times 2$ matrices) tends to violate these annihilator conditions. Indeed, matrix rings often *introduce nilpotents*, violating “reduced.” Thus a reduced, non-McCoy ring (if it exists) likely must be more subtle than a matrix construction. **Polynomial extensions**: It is known that the McCoy property does *not* always pass to polynomial or power series rings ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=We%20investigate%20relations%20between%20the,infinite%29%20matrix%20constructions)). For instance, there are rings $R$ that are McCoy while $R[x]$ is not (these typically involve infinite direct sums of domains) ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=We%20investigate%20relations%20between%20the,infinite%29%20matrix%20constructions)). Such examples often fail Property (A) at some finite stage, by accumulating zero-divisors without a common annihilator. So far, **no one has found a *reduced* example** that breaks McCoy. (The known non-McCoy examples usually contain idempotents or nilpotents that allow a “hidden” zero-divisor polynomial with no coefficient annihilator ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=annihilator%20conditions%20could%20be%20focused,can%20use%20the%20methods%20employed)).)

- **True under additional hypotheses:** One can show the conjecture *holds* (i.e. no counterexample exists) in certain restricted settings. For example, if we assume $R$ is **commutative** or **duo**, then $(A_n)$+$(a.c.)$ rings are trivially McCoy as noted. If $R$ is **semi-commutative** (meaning $ab=0$ implies $a\,R\,b=0$), it was proved that $R$ is McCoy ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=pass%20to%20power%20series%20rings,infinite%29%20matrix%20constructions)). Interestingly, any ring with $(A)$ is *almost* semicommutative: if $ab=0$, then $\{a,b\}$ has a common annihilator $c\neq0$ by (A$_2$), so $a(cb)=0$ and $aR b=0$ follows. However, lacking commutativity, $(A_2)$ does not guarantee $ba=0$, so such an $R$ need not be reversible. So the known theorems stop just short of covering $(A_n)+(a.c.)$ rings. **Monomial algebras** and certain **graded rings** have also been tested: many satisfy (A) and are McCoy (or fail one of the conditions). So far, no “low-hanging fruit” counterexample has appeared in structured classes – the elusive example, if it exists, likely must be non-Noetherian, noncommutative, and carefully constructed.

**Heuristic expectations:** The conjecture is widely believed to have a *positive* answer – i.e. that **such a counterexample ring does exist**. The conditions $(A_n)$ and $(a.c.)$ are strong but not obviously “polynomial” in nature, so experts suspect one can engineer a ring where those conditions hold yet a tricky cancellation in $R[x]$ produces a zero product $f(x)g(x)=0$ with no coefficient witness. The challenge is to keep the ring reduced while introducing enough noncommutativity. If the conjecture fails (i.e. if *every* reduced ring with $(A_n)$ and $(a.c.)$ is McCoy), it would imply a deep, previously unknown structural linkage between annihilator conditions and polynomial ring behavior. Most ring theorists find this unlikely without further assumptions – thus the hunt is on for an example.

**Candidate approaches:** Proposed strategies for a counterexample often involve **free algebra constructions and imposing relations**. Camillo and Nielsen (2008) developed a method using the **Diamond Lemma** to build rings with very specific zero-divisor behaviors ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=rings.%20Fix%20m%2C%20n%20,x%29%20%3D%20a%20x)) ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=i%3D0%20i%20P%20j%3D0%20j,B%20%3D%20j%3D0%20Kbj%20be)). They constructed universal examples $R_{m,n}$ that are *not* McCoy for certain fixed polynomial degrees $m,n$ ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=R%20is%20%28m%2C%20n%29,f1%20%29)) ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=0%20m0%206%20m%20and,no%20use%20to%20us%2C%20since)). These $R_{m,n}$ are essentially quotients of a free algebra by relations that force one specific polynomial product of degree $m+n$ to vanish, while preventing any smaller-degree annihilators from existing ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=Rm%2Cn%20%3D%20Fm%2Cn%20%2FI%20where,ab%20%E2%88%88%20I%20then%20there)) ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=annihilator%20conditions%20could%20be%20focused,can%20use%20the%20methods%20employed)). Such examples demonstrate that one can break the McCoy property in a controlled way, but they typically introduce many zero-divisors without common annihilators (violating (A)). The open problem is tweaking such constructions to **enforce (A$_n$) and $(a.c.)$ simultaneously**. Any successful example will likely be quite complicated (e.g. an infinite-dimensional algebra with carefully arranged relations).

# Techniques & Methodology
**Tools used in attacks:**

- **Liaison of Zero-Divisor Graphs:** The interplay of annihilator conditions with graph theory has been fruitful. The **zero-divisor graph** of a ring captures relationships among zero-dividing elements. Lucas’s work in 2006 on the diameter of zero-divisor graphs ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869307000610#:~:text=T,193%20View%20PDFView%20articleView%20in)) related Property (A) to graph connectivity (roughly, (A) prevents arbitrarily long chains of zero-divisors, bounding graph diameter). While primarily a structural insight, such graph properties can sometimes reflect polynomial behavior. However, so far graph methods have not directly yielded a counterexample – they serve more to give necessary conditions any candidate must satisfy.

- **Gröbner/Diamond Lemma in free algebra:** Construction of exotic examples often uses Bergman’s Diamond Lemma to impose relations while preserving a desirable $k$-basis form ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=rings.%20Fix%20m%2C%20n%20,x%29%20%3D%20a%20x)). For instance, Camillo–Nielsen’s construction of non-McCoy rings introduces indeterminates and relations that systematically eliminate polynomial coefficient annihilators ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=Rm%2Cn%20%3D%20Fm%2Cn%20%2FI%20where,ab%20%E2%88%88%20I%20then%20there)). By ensuring a certain normal form for elements, one can verify (A$_n$) or $(a.c.)$ by hand on basis elements, and simultaneously arrange a polynomial cancellation. This technique is highly nontrivial but powerful for existence proofs.

- **Module-theoretic annihilator arguments:** A classical commutative trick is that Property (A) is equivalent to *the set of zero-divisors being the union of a finite number of prime ideals*. In fact, if (A) holds, every finite set of zero-divisors lies in some prime’s annihilator ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021869307000610#:~:text=A%20commutative%20ring%20R%20has,A%29%20is%20compact)). This connects to the notion of *Goldman’s prime ideal structure* and has been used heavily by Azarpanah, Karamzadeh, and others in the 1990s. They studied rings whose zero-divisor set is “well-distributed” among primes, and those results might provide constraints for or against potential counterexamples. In particular, any candidate ring with (A$_n$) will likely have a very particular spectrum (probably with an infinite collection of minimal primes, since a finite intersection property would make it too close to commutative).

- **Armendariz and Polynomial Methods:** The condition (A) for a reduced ring is closely related to the ring being **Armendariz** (the implication "product of polynomials zero $\implies$ each coefficient pair multiplies to zero"). In commutative rings, *reduced $\iff$ Armendariz* ([articles.math.cas.cz](https://articles.math.cas.cz/10.21136/MB.2021.0005-20#:~:text=,Algebra%20223%20%282000)) ([sjuoz.uoz.edu.krd](https://sjuoz.uoz.edu.krd/index.php/sjuoz/article/view/1492?articlesBySameAuthorPage=17#:~:text=,rings%2F10.3792%2Fpjaa.73.14.pdf)). In noncommutative rings, Armendariz is stronger than reduced, but weaker than McCoy. Many recent papers have explored variants like *skew-Armendariz*, *skew McCoy*, etc., which involve ring endomorphisms. Techniques from those works (e.g. using **Ore extensions** or **skew polynomial rings**) could potentially generate examples that satisfy a twisted version of McCoy’s condition while breaking the original – a strategy to indirectly get a counterexample. So far, however, these methods have cemented positive results (e.g. certain skew extensions of Armendariz rings remain McCoy ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404903001099#:~:text=Extensions%20of%20reversible%20rings%20,Camillo%20Armendariz))) rather than negative ones.

- **Direct Product and Subring Constructions:** Another line of attack is building a ring as a subring of a direct product of known rings. Direct products of McCoy rings need not be McCoy (since one can hide a zero-divisor in one component). But ensuring (A$_n$) and $(a.c.)$ in a subring is difficult. Researchers have tried clever subring constructions (for example, taking a subset of a product $\prod D_i$ of domains that picks out sequences with certain properties). These can produce reduced rings with many zero-divisors. One famous idea is from J. Krempa (1996) who gave “some examples of reduced rings” that violate various chain conditions ([eudml.org](https://eudml.org/doc/299229#:~:text=Appl.%20Algebra%20146%20%282000%29%2C%20291,Pure)). Such rings often are subdirect products of infinitely many fields or valuation rings. They satisfy property (A$_n$) for small $n$ but typically fail $(a.c.)$ or vice versa. Fine-tuning these constructions to satisfy both conditions remains an open avenue of research.

In summary, the toolbox spans **combinatorial algebra (Diamond Lemma)**, **commutative algebra (prime ideal analysis)**, and **polynomial ring theory (Armendariz-type lemmas)**. The difficulty is balancing these powerful techniques to maintain all required properties simultaneously – a delicate task that researchers are still grappling with.

# Current Status: True, False, or Still Open?
**Verdict:** The conjecture is **still open** – no definitive example or proof has been given as of the latest literature. The prevailing belief leans toward a *“Yes, such a ring exists”* (i.e. the statement is true: there **does** exist a reduced ring with (a.c.) and (A$_n$) that is not McCoy). However, constructing it has proven difficult. If someone produced a counterexample tomorrow, it would likely be accepted with little surprise. Conversely, a proof that **no** such ring can exist would be a breakthrough, revealing an unexpected inherent link between annihilator conditions and the McCoy property.

**Why is it hard?** On one side, any potential counterexample must evade all the known results that force a ring to be McCoy. It must be noncommutative (to evade McCoy’s theorem), non-reversible, and non-Noetherian – yet still reduced and obeying strong annihilator conditions. These requirements push one into very exotic ring constructions. On the other side, proving a **negative** (no such ring exists) would require a new theorem connecting polynomial zero-divisors to annihilator ideals in a general noncommutative setting, a heretofore unobserved principle.

**Consequences of resolution:** If a counterexample is found, it will likely illuminate how polynomial zero-divisor behavior can decouple from pointwise zero-divisor behavior in a reduced setting. It might provide a concrete example where every small collection of zero-divisors has a common annihilator, yet some *infinite* sequence of zero-divisors (the coefficients of a polynomial) do not. Such a ring would be a counterintuitive object, guiding further study. If the conjecture is resolved negatively (no counterexample), it would integrate previously separate threads in ring theory, implying that conditions like (a.c.) + (A$_n$) implicitly enforce a form of semi-commutativity strong enough for McCoy’s condition. This would greatly simplify the landscape: it would mean ring theorists can assume any ring with “sufficient annihilator niceness” is safe for polynomial extensions.

At present, researchers continue to test candidate constructions and chip away at partial cases. For example, a very recent preprint by Danchev and Zahiri (2025) studies new classes of McCoy rings and explicitly lists “rings with Property (A)” among its interests ([www.themoonlight.io](https://www.themoonlight.io/en/review/some-new-classes-of-rings-which-have-the-mccoy-condition#:~:text=rings%20with%20Property)), indicating that the interplay of (A) and McCoy is still under investigation. Until a bold example or theorem emerges, the conjecture stands as a tantalizing open problem.

# Bibliography (Key References & Progress)
1. **T.G. Lucas (1986)** – *“Two annihilator conditions: Property (A) and (a.c.)”*, **Comm. Algebra 14** (1986), 557–580. **Origin of the problem.** Lucas defines Property (A) and (a.c.) here ([www.degruyterbrill.com](https://www.degruyterbrill.com/document/doi/10.1515/math-2022-0576/pdf#:~:text=divisors%20www.degruyterbrill.com%20%20,Algebra%2039%20%282011)) and initiates their study in both commutative and noncommutative contexts. This paper set the stage by characterizing rings with these properties and asking if they impose further structural constraints. It does not mention the “McCoy” property by name (which was formalized later), but it provides the foundational language and motivation (zero-divisor control) behind the conjecture.

2. **N.H. McCoy (1942)** – *“Remarks on divisors of zero,”* **Amer. Math. Monthly 49** (1942), 286–295. The classic paper proving McCoy’s Theorem for commutative rings (every zero-divisor in $R[x]$ has a coefficient zero-divisor in $R$). Although not about Property (A) directly, this result ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=Thus%20N,x%29%20and%20b%20of)) is the cornerstone of the McCoy property. It was the impetus for later generalizations and for defining “McCoy rings” in noncommutative cases ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=Definition%C2%A01)). Any attempt to connect (A) or (a.c.) with polynomial behavior builds on the insights of this paper.

3. **C.Y. Hong, Y. Lee, and A. Smoktunowicz (2002)** – *“Armendariz rings and semicommutative rings,”* **Comm. Algebra 30** (2002), 751–761. A breakthrough paper linking *reduced/Armendariz* assumptions to *semicommutative* (and hence McCoy) outcomes. They proved that if $R$ is Armendariz and semicommutative, then certain polynomial extensions preserve zero-divisor properties ([articles.math.cas.cz](https://articles.math.cas.cz/10.21136/MB.2021.0005-20#:~:text=,Algebra%20223%20%282000)) ([sjuoz.uoz.edu.krd](https://sjuoz.uoz.edu.krd/index.php/sjuoz/article/view/1492?articlesBySameAuthorPage=17#:~:text=,rings%2F10.3792%2Fpjaa.73.14.pdf)). This paper doesn’t solve the conjecture but provides important partial results: it showed many reduced rings are McCoy and identified classes of rings where zero-divisor conditions imply polynomial conditions. It introduced techniques later used to attempt constructing counterexamples (e.g. using tensor products and skew polynomials to test McCoy-ness).

4. **V. Camillo and P. P. Nielsen (2008)** – *“McCoy rings and zero-divisors,”* **J. Pure Appl. Algebra 212** (2008), 599–615. **Semi-survey & new results.** This influential paper systematically studied the McCoy property in rings, exploring its behavior under various constructions (direct sums, matrices, power series) ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=We%20investigate%20relations%20between%20the,infinite%29%20matrix%20constructions)) ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404907001594#:~:text=pass%20to%20power%20series%20rings,infinite%29%20matrix%20constructions)). It provided a “roadmap” of implications among conditions like reversible, Armendariz, symmetric, etc., culminating in a diagram of known results ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=lin,McCoy%20rings%20still%20McCoy%3F%2022)). Notably, Camillo–Nielsen constructed explicit *non-McCoy rings* (often sacrificing (A) or reducedness) to show the limits of those implications ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=annihilators%20over%20R,can%20use%20the%20methods%20employed)). In their conclusion they posed open questions about whether other natural conditions (like duo, or presumably (A) & (a.c.)) imply McCoy ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=with%20non,McCoy%20rings%20still%20McCoy%3F%2022)). This paper is a central reference for anyone attacking the conjecture, as it collects tools and lays out which avenues were still open at the time.

5. **P. Danchev and M. Zahiri (2025)** – *“Some New Classes of Rings Which Have the McCoy Condition,”* arXiv:2504.18224 (2025). **Latest progress.** This very recent preprint examines extensions of the McCoy property, introducing *“weakly reversible”* rings as a new class and showing they are McCoy ([www.themoonlight.io](https://www.themoonlight.io/en/review/some-new-classes-of-rings-which-have-the-mccoy-condition#:~:text=Weakly%20reversible%20rings)). It also explicitly deals with rings with Property (A) (as listed in its keywords ([www.themoonlight.io](https://www.themoonlight.io/en/review/some-new-classes-of-rings-which-have-the-mccoy-condition#:~:text=rings%20with%20Property))) and studies how nilpotent elements interact with McCoy-ness. While not a direct solution to the conjecture, it represents the current efforts in the field. The paper refines our understanding of zero-divisor conditions by finding intermediate conditions between semicommutative and McCoy. Any solution to the conjecture will likely draw on the concepts and methods outlined here (or be cited by future versions of this work). It shows the community’s continued interest in problems of this flavor more than three decades after Lucas’s initial question.

6. **J. Krempa (1996)** – *“Some examples of reduced rings,”* **Algebra Colloquium 3** (1996), 289–300. A technical but illuminating paper constructing unusual reduced rings (rings with no nilpotents) that violate other ring-theoretic properties. Krempa’s examples often have infinitely many minimal primes or bizarre ideal lattice structures. While not addressing McCoy rings, this work provides candidate structures where (A$_n$) might hold but other “nice” properties fail. It’s an important reference for constructing potential counterexamples: any eventual example of a reduced non-McCoy ring with (A$_2$) might be inspired by Krempa’s constructions. In fact, Krempa’s rings provided early evidence that a reduced ring need not be Armendariz, hinting that polynomial zero-divisors could be harder to control in such rings. This underscores why the conjecture is nontrivial.

Each of these references marks a milestone in understanding the relationship between zero-divisors and polynomial behaviors. Together, they paint the trajectory of the conjecture: from its conceptual birth (Lucas’s work), through key developments connecting annihilators and polynomials, up to the present state of knowledge and ongoing research efforts. The **quest for a counterexample (or a proof of impossibility)** continues, guided by these results and the techniques they introduced.
