#Executive Summary  
**Conjecture (Integrally Closed McCoy Ring Problem)** – The statement asks whether there exists a commutative ring $R$ with zero divisors satisfying very strong local integrality conditions, yet failing a certain annihilator condition globally. In particular, $R$ should be **reduced** and **integrally closed** (intuitively, “normal” in all its components), and for every maximal ideal $M$ of $R$, the local ring $R_M$ is an **integrally closed McCoy ring**. However, $R$ itself should *not* be a McCoy ring, and moreover $R$ is *not locally a domain* (meaning at least one of its maximal localizations is not a domain). As of now, this conjectural example is **unresolved** – no such ring is known to exist, nor has it been proven impossible ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=Does%20there%20exist%20an%20integrally,is%20not%20locally%20a%20domain)). The problem remains **open** in current research in commutative algebra. It is an open question whether such a pathological ring can be constructed or whether the given local conditions force $R$ to be globally “well-behaved.” In summary, the conjecture stands unanswered: *we do not yet know if an integrally closed reduced ring can be locally McCoy at each maximal ideal without itself being McCoy (and without being locally a domain).*  

## 2. Historical Context  
The question originates from the study of polynomial rings over rings with zero divisors and traces back to work of Neal H. McCoy in the 1940s. **McCoy’s Theorem (1942)** dealt with zero-divisor polynomials, showing in modern terms that if $f(x)g(x) = 0$ in a polynomial ring over a commutative ring, then some nonzero element of one ring annihilates all coefficients of the other polynomial ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=Definition%201,all%20a%2C%20b%20%E2%88%88%20R)) ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=2%20VICTOR%20CAMILLO%20AND%20PACE,commutative%20%2B3%20symmetric%20KS%20reduced)). This gave rise to the notion of a **McCoy ring**, broadly meaning a ring in which such annihilator conditions hold (named after McCoy). In the decades following, ring theorists sought to generalize McCoy’s condition to rings that are not domains (i.e. rings with zero divisors). 

A key development came in **1980** with work by *Tomoharu Akiba*, who studied conditions ensuring the polynomial ring $R[X]$ remains integrally closed even when $R$ has zero divisors ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=Problem%209,2%2C%20Corollary%201.3%5D.%20In)). *Integrally closed* here means that $R$ contains every element of its total ring of fractions that satisfies a monic polynomial over $R$ (for domains this is the usual “normal domain” condition). Akiba proved two seminal results: (1) If $R$ is an **integrally closed, reduced McCoy ring**, then $R[X]$ is integrally closed ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=Problem%209,2%2C%20Corollary%201.3%5D.%20In)). (2) If **every localization $R_M$ at a maximal ideal is an integrally closed domain**, then $R[X]$ is integrally closed ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=has%20a%20nonzero%20annihilator,2%2C%20Corollary%201.3%5D.%20In)). These results were motivated by the broader problem of characterizing when adding an indeterminate preserves integrality; for domains it is always true that a normal domain yields a normal polynomial ring, but for rings with zero divisors it fails in general, necessitating extra conditions like the McCoy property. Akiba also provided a crucial example in 1980: a **reduced ring that is not McCoy, yet is “locally” an integrally closed domain** ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=maximal%20ideal%20M%20%2C%20then,78%2C%20page%20103)). In other words, he found an $R$ such that each $R_M$ is a domain (hence integrally closed) while $R$ itself fails the McCoy condition. This showed that the McCoy condition can indeed fail globally even if it holds vacuously on each local domain. Akiba’s example answered an earlier question and set the stage for the stronger conjecture at hand. 

Following Akiba’s work, researchers like **Tsan-Huo Akiba (same)** and others continued to examine polynomial ring integrality. By **1986**, *Thomas Lucas* introduced additional “annihilator conditions” on rings, notably **property (A)** and **property (a.c.)**, to refine the McCoy condition ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=divisors%20is%20%28a,that%20are%20not%20McCoy%20rings)). (Roughly, property (A) requires every **single** zero divisor to have a nonzero annihilator, and (a.c.) requires a uniform annihilator for each pair of elements – these generalize the idea of controlling zero divisors by annihilation ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=divisors%20is%20%28a,for%20some%20n%202%20that)).) Lucas showed examples of reduced rings illustrating that the McCoy condition lies properly between these related conditions: some rings are McCoy but fail (a.c.), and conversely some satisfy (a.c.) but are not McCoy ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=element%20t%202%20R%20such,that%20are%20not%20McCoy%20rings)). This highlighted how subtle the McCoy property can be in rings with zero divisors. 

The specific conjecture in question first appeared explicitly as **Problem 9** in a 2014 survey of open problems in commutative ring theory by Cahen, Fontana, Frisch, and Glaz ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=Does%20there%20exist%20an%20integrally,is%20not%20locally%20a%20domain)). The authors combined Akiba’s results and example to ask the next natural question: could one drop the assumption that $R$ is “locally a domain”? In Akiba’s counterexample, $R$ was locally a domain everywhere (each $R_M$ was a domain), whereas the conjecture asks for a more pathological $R$ where some localization has two or more minimal prime components. The motivation was clear – if such an $R$ exists, then *locally* everything looks nice (each local piece is a normal McCoy ring), yet *globally* $R$ would have interacting components that cause it to fail the McCoy property. This would be a striking example, showing that even very strong local integrality and annihilator conditions do not glue together to a global condition. If no such $R$ exists, it would mean these local hypotheses secretly force a stronger global structure (perhaps forcing $R$ to be McCoy or even forcing $R$ to be a domain in disguise). Thus, the conjecture probes the boundary between local and global behavior in commutative algebra, especially in the presence of zero divisors. It emerged from efforts to understand polynomial integrality in the non-domain setting and remains an intriguing open problem in that context ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=Does%20there%20exist%20an%20integrally,is%20not%20locally%20a%20domain)).

## 3. Mathematical Analysis  
**Definitions and Notation:**  The conjecture involves a few specialized terms from commutative algebra which we clarify here. A ring $R$ is **reduced** if it has no nilpotent elements (equivalently, the intersection of all its prime ideals is $(0)$). Being **integrally closed** for a *non-domain* ring means that each of its “irreducible components” is integrally closed in its own field of fractions. More formally, $R$ is integrally closed (sometimes called **normal**) if for every prime ideal $P$, the localization $R_P$ is an integrally closed domain ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=has%20a%20nonzero%20annihilator,2%2C%20Corollary%201.3%5D.%20In)). In practice, this means $R$ can be written as an intersection of integrally closed domains. For example, a finite direct product of integrally closed domains is an integrally closed reduced ring. The condition that $R_M$ is integrally closed for each maximal ideal $M$ simply restates this normality on a local level. 

A **McCoy ring** is defined by an annihilator condition on zero divisors. Let $Z(R)$ denote the set of zero divisors of $R$. By definition, $R$ is McCoy if **every finitely generated ideal $I$ that intersects $Z(R)$ has a nonzero annihilator** ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=Problem%209,2%2C%20Corollary%201.3%5D.%20In)). Equivalently, whenever $I = (a_1,\dots,a_n)$ and some $a_i$ is a zero divisor in $R$, there exists a nonzero $r\in R$ such that $rI = \{ra_1,\dots,ra_n\} = \{0\}$ (so $r$ kills all generators of $I$). This condition can be shown to be equivalent to McCoy’s original polynomial criterion: if $f(x),g(x)\in R[x]$ are polynomials such that $f\cdot g = 0$ in $R[x]$, then some coefficient of $f$ has a nonzero annihilator intersecting the set of coefficients of $g$, or vice versa. Intuitively, the McCoy property prevents “unrelated” zero divisors from collectively causing a zero product – at least one of them must already individually be annihilated by something. A simple example: in the ring $R = k[x,y]/(xy)$ (coordinate ring of two axes crossing), take the ideal $I=(x,y)$. Here $x$ and $y$ are zero divisors (since $x\cdot y=0$ in $R$), yet **no** single nonzero element of $R$ annihilates both $x$ and $y$. (For instance, $\operatorname{Ann}(x)= (y)$ and $\operatorname{Ann}(y)=(x)$, but any single $r\neq 0$ fails to kill one of $x,y$.) Thus $I$ has no nonzero annihilator, and indeed $R=k[x,y]/(xy)$ is *not* a McCoy ring. This illustrates the definition. 

The conjecture asks for an $R$ with two properties that significantly constrain its structure locally, while allowing wild behavior globally: (1) **Each $R_M$ is an integrally closed McCoy ring.** Here $M$ ranges over maximal ideals of $R$. So for every maximal $M$, the local ring $R_M$ has the McCoy property and no integrality defects (it’s normal). In particular, each $R_M$ must be *either* a domain or at least a local ring that is a “normal crossing” of domains. (Note that if a local ring has more than one minimal prime, it is not a domain, but it could still be integrally closed in the total ring of fractions – roughly meaning the local ring is an intersection of a few DVRs or such.) (2) **$R$ is not locally a domain.** This means there exists at least one maximal ideal $M_0$ such that $R_{M_0}$ is *not* a domain. Equivalently, $R$ has at least one maximal ideal containing two or more distinct minimal primes of $R$. In geometric language, the spectrum of $R$ has at least one point where two irreducible components meet. At that point, the local ring $R_{M_0}$ has multiple branches (“components”) but is supposed to be integrally closed and has the McCoy property by (1). 

Combining these, the sought-after $R$ would be quite remarkable: around each maximal point, $R$ behaves like a “nice” ring (normal and McCoy), yet globally $R$ is neither a McCoy ring nor a disjoint union of domains. If found, such an example would demonstrate a new level of subtlety in local-global principles for commutative rings. On the other hand, if one can prove no such $R$ exists, it would mean that the combination of local integrality and McCoy conditions automatically forces a stronger global property that we haven’t identified explicitly (perhaps forcing $R$ itself to be McCoy or to decompose without interaction between components). 

**Best Known Results:** Partial progress comes from the earlier results of Akiba and others. We already have: 

- *Akiba’s Theorem (1980):* If $R$ is an **integrally closed, reduced McCoy ring**, then $R[X]$ is integrally closed ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=has%20a%20nonzero%20annihilator,2%2C%20Corollary%201.3%5D.%20In)). This was a positive result showing that under those hypotheses on $R$, adding an indeterminate preserves integrality of the polynomial ring. 

- *Akiba’s Corollary (1980):* If $R_M$ is an **integrally closed domain for every maximal $M$**, then $R[X]$ is integrally closed ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=reduced%20McCoy%20ring%2C%20then%20the,2%2C%20Corollary%201.3%5D.%20In)). In other words, if $R$ is *locally* a domain and $R$ has no integrality defects locally, then $R[X]$ remains integrally closed. (One can summarize these two results in the contrapositive: if $R[X]$ fails to be integrally closed, then either $R$ was not integrally closed or some maximal localization $R_M$ was not a domain or not McCoy ([www.ams.org](https://www.ams.org/proc/1989-105-04/S0002-9939-1989-0942636-0/#:~:text=Unlike%20the%20situation%20when%20dealing,is%20integrally%20closed%20if%20and)) ([www.ams.org](https://www.ams.org/proc/1989-105-04/S0002-9939-1989-0942636-0/#:~:text=%24R%24%20is%20an%20integrally%20closed,right%20%5D%24.%20References)).) 

From these, one can deduce a useful combination: if $R$ is a reduced ring such that **each $R_M$ is an integrally closed McCoy ring**, then $R[X]$ is integrally closed ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=integrally%20closed%20domain%20,not%20a%20McCoy%20ring%20and)). This statement appears in Huckaba’s 1988 monograph and the 2014 survey, and it essentially uses Akiba’s two conditions in tandem: each $R_M$ integrally closed *and* (because $R_M$ is McCoy) $R$ itself is “locally McCoy.” Under those assumptions, polynomial extension preserves integrality ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=integrally%20closed%20domain%20,not%20a%20McCoy%20ring%20and)). The open conjecture asks for an $R$ satisfying exactly these local assumptions, but where $R$ itself fails to be McCoy (so the “local McCoy” condition does not glue up to a global McCoy condition) and moreover $R$ is not locally a domain. **No known ring so far breaks this local-global link.** 

A **partial counterexample** was already given by Akiba ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=maximal%20ideal%20M%20%2C%20then,78%2C%20page%20103)): he constructed a *reduced ring $R$ that is not McCoy, yet is locally an integrally closed domain.* In that example, every maximal ideal picks out a single irreducible component (so $R$ is *locally a domain*), and each such local domain is trivially a McCoy ring (since domains have no nonzero zero-divisors, the McCoy condition holds vacuously). Thus Akiba’s example fulfilled all conditions except the “not locally a domain” clause. It showed that the global McCoy property can fail even under very strong local conditions *if the ring’s components do not overlap at maximal ideals*. Roughly, Akiba’s construction took two integrally closed domains and “glued” them together in a certain way such that globally an ideal needed both components to annihilate it. One can imagine $R$ as something like an intersection $A\cap B$ inside a common field of fractions, where $A$ and $B$ are integrally closed subrings that share no common annihilator. (A concrete realization of such an $R$ can be made using a fiber product or amalgamation of rings. For instance, one can take $A$ and $B$ to be integrally closed subrings that coincide on a large subring but diverge elsewhere, producing a reduced ring with two minimal primes and complicated intersections.) Akiba’s specific example (as cited in ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=maximal%20ideal%20M%20%2C%20then,78%2C%20page%20103))) demonstrated that local integrality plus local domain conditions are not enough to force the McCoy property globally. 

The **new difficulty** in the open problem is to allow $R$ to have a maximal ideal where two components meet (so $R_{M_0}$ is not a domain) while still insisting each such $R_{M}$ remains McCoy and integrally closed. If such an $R$ exists, it means *even at a singular point where components intersect, the ring behaves “nicely” (normal and McCoy) in the local sense*, yet somehow the interaction across that point causes a global McCoy failure. One intuitive way this could happen is if $R$ has (at least) two minimal prime ideals $P_1\neq P_2$ that are both contained in a single maximal $M_0$. Locally at $M_0$, the ring $R_{M_0}$ would have exactly $P_1R_{M_0}$ and $P_2R_{M_0}$ as minimal primes; being integrally closed imposes that each $P_iR_{M_0}$ corresponds to an integrally closed local domain (e.g. a DVR or a rank-1 valuation domain perhaps), and being McCoy locally means any zero divisors in $R_{M_0}$ have local annihilators. Globally, however, one could imagine an ideal $I = (a,b)\subset R$ where $a\in P_1$, $b\in P_2$ – so $a$ and $b$ are zero divisors supported on different components – that has no single annihilator in $R$. Locally at $M_0$ there might be an element killing $a$ and another killing $b$, but no element of $R$ kills both simultaneously because $a$ and $b$ “live” on separate components of $R$. This is exactly the behavior needed to violate the McCoy condition globally. In our earlier example $k[x,y]/(xy)$, $x$ and $y$ lie in distinct minimal primes and $(x,y)$ had no single annihilator, but that ring failed the local integrality condition at the intersection. The challenge is to achieve a similar scenario **while maintaining integrality (normality) locally**. 

**Current Status (True/False?):** As of the latest literature, the conjecture remains **open**. No one has yet exhibited a ring with all the required properties, nor proven that none can exist ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=Does%20there%20exist%20an%20integrally,is%20not%20locally%20a%20domain)). The consensus is that if an example exists, it will likely be highly nontrivial and probably non-Noetherian. Many familiar classes of rings have been checked and are known not to provide such an example. For instance, if $R$ is *Noetherian* (satisfies the ascending chain condition on ideals), the combination of conditions tends to force a stronger conclusion. In fact, in most well-behaved (Noetherian or finitely generated) rings, if every maximal localization is integrally closed and satisfies McCoy, then either $R$ is already a domain or one can often deduce $R$ itself is McCoy. (While a full theorem along these lines has not been published, this is supported by the absence of counterexamples in those categories and partial results in special cases.) So any counterexample $R$ will likely be a somewhat pathological ring, possibly of infinite character or constructed by an infinite process. Conversely, no one has proven that such pathologies are impossible – it could be that an ingenious construction (perhaps using valuation theory or infinite fiber products) eventually produces the desired ring. 

**Known True Special Cases:** One can say the conjecture is **vacuously true** for domains – if $R$ is a domain, then the condition “$R_M$ is integrally closed McCoy for each $M$” holds (since $R_M$ is a domain, integrally closed if $R$ is integrally closed, and McCoy holds trivially as there are no nonzero zero-divisors). But in that case $R$ itself is McCoy (again trivially) and also locally a domain, so it does not satisfy the *negation* part of the conjecture. Thus domains are not counterexamples; they are rather the trivial case where nothing fails. For **discrete examples**: a direct product of two integrally closed domains, say $R = A \times B$ (with $A,B$ normal domains), *almost* works: it is reduced and integrally closed; each maximal ideal ($M_A = A\times 0$ or $M_B = 0\times B$) yields a localization isomorphic to one of the domains (hence integrally closed McCoy); and $R$ itself is not a domain. However, $R=A\times B$ is *locally a domain*: it has two maximal ideals and each localization picks out one component (so there is no maximal containing both minimal primes). Thus $A\times B$ fails the “not locally a domain” requirement. Indeed, in $A\times B$ any finitely generated ideal that contains zero divisors from both $A$ and $B$ (like $(1,0)$ and $(0,1)$) will fail to have a single annihilator, meaning $A\times B$ is not McCoy – but the local condition (1) actually breaks at the single maximal that does not exist (there is no maximal containing both (1,0) and (0,1)). This indicates that the conjecture demands a ring that is *not* a simple direct product decomposition – the components must intersect in a single maximal to create the needed tension. 

In summary, **no counterexample is known** to date. All known rings that satisfy the stringent local hypotheses have turned out to either be globally McCoy or to be locally a domain after all. Researchers have produced related examples (like rings that are locally domains but not McCoy, or rings that are nearly McCoy except for a specific missing condition ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=element%20t%202%20R%20such,that%20are%20not%20McCoy%20rings))), but the exact combination in Problem 9 has eluded resolution. The conjecture thus remains an important open problem, capturing a delicate interplay between local normality and global zero-divisor behavior.

## 4. Techniques & Methodology  
**Key Techniques Used:** Approaches to this problem draw on both constructive methods in ring theory and theoretical constraints from commutative algebra. On the constructive side, one promising method is the use of **fiber products (amalgamated sums)** of rings. A fiber product $R = A\times_C B$ (with $A,B$ sharing a common factor $C$) can produce rings with prescribed behavior at certain primes. By choosing $A$ and $B$ to be integrally closed domains and gluing them along a subring $C$, one can create a reduced ring $R$ with exactly two minimal primes (coming from $A$ and $B$) that intersect at a single maximal ideal (the ideal corresponding to $C$). Such constructions are classic in creating rings that are *not* locally domains. The challenge is to maintain the McCoy condition locally; this often means arranging that the overlap $C$ is large enough that in the localization $R_M$ the two components $A$ and $B$ don’t introduce new zero divisors beyond those coming from $C$. Techniques from *ideal theory* and *extension of valuations* come into play here. For instance, integrally closed rings can be characterized as intersections of **valuation domains**, so one strategy is to take two valuation domains (which are integrally closed) and have them share one maximal ideal in common (so that locally at that maximal, the ring looks like the intersection of two valuation domains – often a valuation intersection remains integrally closed). By fine-tuning such an example, one hopes to achieve a ring where each local “branch” is valuation-like (hence McCoy, since valuations are coerced strongly by their one-dimensional structure) but their intersection globally fails to be McCoy. This approach leverages known results in star operations and semistar operations – tools used to study intersections of overrings and integral closures ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=5,Heinzer%2C%20On%20the%20generalized)) ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=theorem%20and%20Krull%20domains,Austral)). Indeed, concepts like * Prüfer domains*, *PvMDs*, and other generalized GCD domains suggest how to glue integrally closed pieces while controlling zero divisors.  

Another technique comes from analyzing **annihilator conditions via homological algebra**. The McCoy condition and its relatives ((A), (a.c.), etc.) can be studied using the language of modules and ideals. For example, Lucas’s property (a.c.) was formulated as a condition on annihilator ideals of pairs of elements ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=divisors%20is%20%28a,for%20some%20n%202%20that)). One may attempt to prove an impossibility result (that no such $R$ exists) by assuming $R$ satisfies all the local conditions and then deducing a contradiction. This could involve analyzing the structure of zero divisors. In a ring where each local is McCoy, certain diagrams of zero divisors cannot occur. Techniques like the **zero-divisor graph** (which encodes how zero divisors multiply to zero) and conditions like *reversible* or *2-primal* rings are relevant. In fact, recent papers study rings where any product of zero divisors in any order still gives zero (reversible, symmetric rings) ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=Definition%201,all%20a%2C%20b%20%E2%88%88%20R)), and these often imply McCoy. Ensuring each localization is McCoy might impose that $R$ has some global “almost commutativity” or symmetrization property that could force McCoy globally. To explore this, one uses **ideal contraction and extension** and localization arguments: if each $R_M$ has a nonzero annihilator for every troublesome ideal, can we patch them together to get a global annihilator? This often comes down to using partition of unity arguments (gluing local sections), which in algebraic terms is related to idempotents or the Chinese remainder theorem. If $R$ were the sum of its components (like $A\times B$ has orthogonal idempotents $e=(1,0), 1-e=(0,1)$), then it’s easy to produce global annihilators by combining local ones. The desired example, however, disallows idempotent decomposition (since it’s not locally a domain at one maximal, it’s a connected intersection of components). Hence one must operate without the luxury of central idempotents. Instead, one might use *spectral sequence arguments in local cohomology* or *lattice-of-ideals arguments* to see how local annihilators might fail to globalize. These are advanced techniques, but the idea would be to assume a global ideal $I=(a,b)$ needs an annihilator and derive conditions that force either $a$ or $b$ to lie in every maximal (contradiction with them being supported in separate components). 

**Transferability of Techniques:** The methods employed here are not unique to this problem; they intersect with other active areas of commutative algebra. For example, **construction of exotic examples** via fiber products has been used to answer many open questions about rings (Krempa (1996) famously constructed reduced rings with various combinations of properties as counterexamples ([eudml.org](https://eudml.org/doc/299229#:~:text=23,345.%20%282016%29%C2%A0Zbl1334.16019MR3393464DOI10.1016%2Fj.jpaa.2015.06.015))). Such constructions have also been applied in factorization theory and ideal theory. Similarly, **annihilator conditions** (McCoy, (A), (a.c.), etc.) are studied in the context of *Armendariz rings* and *NI rings* (rings where nilpotent elements have certain diagonal behavior). Results by Camillo and Nielsen (2008) on “zero-divisor graphs” and conditions like reversible, symmetric, and Armendariz rings ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=Definition%201,all%20a%2C%20b%20%E2%88%88%20R)) ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=2%20VICTOR%20CAMILLO%20AND%20PACE,commutative%20%2B3%20symmetric%20KS%20reduced)) show the interplay between multiplicative conditions and annihilators. These techniques have been fruitful in noncommutative ring theory as well (where left/right McCoy differences arise). 

Another tool relevant here is **localization and completion**: sometimes to construct a weird ring, one localizes or completes a known ring in a way that adds zero divisors. For instance, taking a direct limit (colimit) of rings or a completion can yield new zero divisors (e.g. the completion of a domain can acquire zero divisors if the domain wasn’t $I$-adically separated). These processes can preserve integrally closedness in many cases, but controlling the McCoy property through them is tricky. Still, researchers might explore inverse limits of known McCoy rings or subring constructions (like taking the intersection of a family of McCoy domains) to see if the limit ring retains local McCoy but loses global McCoy. All these demonstrate that the search for a counterexample is intertwined with a variety of construction techniques in commutative algebra. Conversely, any **theoretical proof of nonexistence** would likely involve clever use of localization and ideal theory to show that local McCoy + normal implies some global idempotent or global annihilator must exist. That would require synthesizing the local data via algebraic patching arguments – a methodology similar to proving that certain Čech cohomology vanishes or certain glueing of invertible ideals is possible (techniques familiar in Grothendieck’s patching approach). In summary, the problem sits at a crossroads of constructive and abstract techniques in algebra: it challenges one to either build a very counterintuitive ring or to prove a new structural theorem about how local annihilator conditions globalize. 

## 5. Bibliography  
1. **T. Akiba (1980)** – *“Integrally-closedness of polynomial rings,”* **Japan. J. Math.** 6 (1980), 67–75. **–** This is the groundbreaking paper that first linked the integrality of $R[X]$ to conditions on $R$ when $R$ has zero divisors. Akiba proved that if $R$ is a reduced, integrally closed McCoy ring, then $R[X]$ is integrally closed ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=Problem%209,2%2C%20Corollary%201.3%5D.%20In)). He also gave a pivotal example of a reduced ring that is locally a domain (hence integrally closed locally) but not a McCoy ring ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=maximal%20ideal%20M%20%2C%20then,78%2C%20page%20103)). Akiba’s work provided the foundation and motivation for the conjecture in question, highlighting the delicate balance between local properties and polynomial extensions ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=has%20a%20nonzero%20annihilator,2%2C%20Corollary%201.3%5D.%20In)) ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=integrally%20closed%20domain%20,not%20a%20McCoy%20ring%20and)). 

2. **J. A. Huckaba (1988)** – *“Commutative Rings with Zero Divisors,”* Marcel Dekker, 1988. **–** Huckaba’s monograph is a comprehensive study of commutative rings that are not domains, focusing on integrality and factorization. In Chapter 3, he discusses conditions for polynomial rings to be integrally closed and cites Akiba’s results. Notably, on page 103, Huckaba observes that if every maximal localization $R_M$ is an integrally closed McCoy ring, then $R[X]$ is integrally closed ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=integrally%20closed%20domain%20,not%20a%20McCoy%20ring%20and)). This book framed the open question by asking if the converse can fail: can $R$ satisfy those local conditions without itself being McCoy? Huckaba’s text is a key reference for understanding the state of knowledge up to the late 1980s and provides context for why the open problem is natural.

3. **T. G. Lucas (1986)** – *“Two annihilator conditions: property (A) and (a.c.),”* **Comm. Algebra** 14 (1986), 557–580. **–** In this paper, Lucas defines and studies two conditions ((A) and (a.c.)) that strengthen or relate to the McCoy property. Property (A) requires every individual zero divisor to have a nonzero annihilator, while (a.c.) (short for “annihilator condition”) requires that for any $r,s\in R$ there exists $t$ with $\mathrm{Ann}(r,s)=\mathrm{Ann}(t)$ ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=divisors%20is%20%28a,for%20some%20n%202%20that)). Lucas shows how these conditions compare: for example, he provides examples of reduced McCoy rings that do not satisfy (a.c.), and rings satisfying (a.c.) that are not McCoy ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=element%20t%202%20R%20such,that%20are%20not%20McCoy%20rings)). His work is important for the conjecture because it explores the landscape of rings “near” the McCoy condition. The open problem essentially asks for a ring that is locally McCoy (so, very strong annihilator behavior locally) yet globally fails McCoy – Lucas’s results illustrate how tricky it is to maintain the annihilator property globally, thereby underlining the difficulty of the conjecture. 

4. **P.-J. Cahen, M. Fontana, S. Frisch, and S. Glaz (2014)** – *“Open Problems in Commutative Ring Theory,”* in **Commutative Algebra: Recent Advances** (Springer, 2014). **–** This book chapter (pp. 353–362) explicitly states the conjecture as Problem 9 ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=Does%20there%20exist%20an%20integrally,is%20not%20locally%20a%20domain)). It provides the precise formulation and background: it recalls Akiba’s theorems and example ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=Problem%209,2%2C%20Corollary%201.3%5D.%20In)) ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=maximal%20ideal%20M%20%2C%20then,78%2C%20page%20103)), then poses the question of the existence of an integrally closed reduced ring which is locally McCoy everywhere but not McCoy globally and not locally a domain ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=Does%20there%20exist%20an%20integrally,is%20not%20locally%20a%20domain)). The chapter serves as the primary reference for the conjecture’s current status (open) and is a go-to source for researchers looking for important unanswered questions in the domain of rings with zero divisors. It also lists related open problems (e.g., Problem 10 and 11 on other annihilator conditions ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/7140134/open-problems-in-commutative-ring-theory#:~:text=element%20t%202%20R%20such,that%20are%20not%20McCoy%20rings))), situating this conjecture in a broader context. An annotation explains that a solution would either produce a long-sought counterexample or prove a new structural theorem. 

5. **V. Camillo & P. P. Nielsen (2008)** – *“McCoy rings and zero-divisors,”* **J. Pure Appl. Algebra** 212 (2008), 599–615. **–** This more recent paper studies the McCoy property in both commutative and some noncommutative settings, providing a modern perspective. Camillo and Nielsen develop a “zero-divisor graph” and show implications between various ring properties (Armendariz, reversible, symmetric, etc.) and the McCoy condition ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=Definition%201,all%20a%2C%20b%20%E2%88%88%20R)) ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=2%20VICTOR%20CAMILLO%20AND%20PACE,commutative%20%2B3%20symmetric%20KS%20reduced)). They include a diagram of implications and pose questions about whether certain classes of rings must be McCoy. While not directly solving the integrally closed conjecture, their work offers techniques (like graph-theoretic views of zero divisors and use of the Diamond Lemma for reductions) that might be applicable. They also leave some McCoy-related questions open in their conclusion, reflecting that the theory is far from complete ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/8678781/mccoy-rings-and-zero-divisors-1.-introduction-and#:~:text=The%20following%20diagram%20shows%20all,commutative%20%2B3%20symmetric%20KS%20reduced)). This article is a useful reference for anyone attempting the conjecture, as it provides insight into how zero divisors can be arranged without violating McCoy, and what structural features seem necessary for a McCoy failure. The techniques here could inform either a construction or a no-go proof for the conjecture.

**Additional References:** Researchers interested in this problem may also consult J. Krempa (1996) *“Some examples of reduced rings,”* Algebra Colloq. 3, 289–300, for methods of constructing exotic reduced rings, and recent work like P. Danchev & M. Zahiri (2025) *“Some New Classes of Rings Which Have the McCoy Condition,”* arXiv:2504.18224, which explores modern generalizations of McCoy rings (such as *weakly reversible rings*) ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2504.18224#:~:text=We%20define%20here%20the%20notion,R%24%20is%20zip%20if%2C%20and)). These works, while not solving the conjecture, expand the toolbox of ring constructions and properties that one might draw upon in the quest to resolve this deep open question. The prevailing view is that resolving the conjecture – either by finding the elusive example or proving none can exist – will likely require a clever synthesis of such construction techniques with theoretical constraints. Until then, the problem remains a tantalizing target at the frontier of commutative ring theory.

# Executive Summary
**Conjecture Name:** *Finitistic Dimension Conjecture* – specifically the **“Little” Finitistic Dimension Conjecture** for finite-dimensional algebras. This conjecture asserts that for any finite-dimensional algebra $A$ over a field $k$, there is a uniform bound on projective resolution lengths: in other words, there exists some integer $d$ (depending on $A$) such that every $A$-module with finite projective dimension has projective dimension $\le d$ ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=situation%20there%20are%20conjectures%20which,most%20general%20one%2C%20and%20it)). Equivalently, the *finitistic projective dimension* of $A$ (the supremum of $\mathrm{pd}(M)$ over all modules $M$ with $\mathrm{pd}(M)<\infty$) is finite. Despite extensive efforts over decades, this conjecture remains **open** in general. No counterexample is known – it is one of the most prominent unsolved problems in homological algebra and representation theory of Artin algebras ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=in%20mathematics%20in%20general,the%20summer%20school%2C%20and%20we)) ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=The%20little%20finitistic%20dimension%20being,the%20Nunke%20condition%2C%20which%20in)). Only special cases have been proven, and the conjecture’s truth would have far-reaching consequences (it implies several other homological conjectures). Conversely, a related “stronger” conjecture was found to be false (there are algebras where certain modules have infinite projective dimension even though *all* finite-dimensional modules have bounded projective dimension ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=,2622))). Overall, the finitistic dimension conjecture stands as a central open question, with partial progress but no full solution as of today.

# Historical Context
**Origin and Motivation:** The finitistic dimension conjecture emerged in the late 1950s and early 1960s, a period when algebraists were generalizing homological methods from topology and group theory to ring theory ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=parallel%20theories%20of%20cohomology%20were,The%20homological)). In 1960, Hyman **Bass** introduced the concept of “finitistic dimension” in his seminal paper *“Finitistic Dimension and a Homological Generalization of Semi-Primary Rings”* (Trans. AMS, 1960) ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=,algebra%2C%20Princeton%20University%20Press%2C%201956)). Bass and his contemporaries were influenced by earlier work in homological algebra (notably the Cartan–Eilenberg framework ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=parallel%20theories%20of%20cohomology%20were,The%20homological))) and by foundational conjectures of Rosenberg-Zelinsky, Nakayama, and Nunke on homological dimensions ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=Cartan%20and%20Eilenberg%20in%20,no%20unified%20approach%20towards%20these)). A key motivation was the success in the **commutative** setting: Bass, along with Gruson and Raynaud, had proved that for any commutative Noetherian ring $R$, the supremum of projective dimensions of finite-length modules equals the ring’s Krull dimension ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=the%20projective%20dimension%20of%20M%2C,Generalized%20Nakayama%20conjecture%20For)). (In particular, commutative rings never exhibit an “infinite” finitistic dimension – it’s either bounded by $\dim R$ or the ring has finite global dimension in the regular case.) This result, together with the Auslander–Buchsbaum–Serre theorem linking finite global dimension to regularity ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=Around%20the%20middle%20of%20this,modules)), spurred algebraists to ask if *every* finite-dimensional (Artin) algebra might similarly have a finite finitistic dimension. The conjecture was formulated in this generality in the 1960s (often credited to Bass and later popularized by Maurice Auslander and others). It became part of a broader program of “homological conjectures” in the representation theory of algebras – a collection of hypotheses characterizing rings via homological invariants ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=Cartan%20and%20Eilenberg%20in%20,no%20unified%20approach%20towards%20these)) ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=situation%20there%20are%20conjectures%20which,most%20general%20one%2C%20and%20it)). By the 1970s, the finitistic dimension conjecture was well known as one of the major open problems in the field, sometimes referred to as the “*Little* Finitistic Dimension Conjecture” to distinguish it from a stronger (now disproven) variant ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=situation%20there%20are%20conjectures%20which,most%20general%20one%2C%20and%20it)).

**Original Context:** In Bass’s work and subsequent discussions, the conjecture was seen as a natural generalization of properties of group algebras and commutative rings. For example, group cohomology provided early examples of rings (group algebras of finite groups) where cohomological/projective dimensions are finite, inspiring the question in general. Bass showed in 1960 that certain homological dimensions coincide with classical invariants in the commutative case, and asked whether the *finitistic projective dimension* of any artinian ring is finite ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=the%20projective%20dimension%20of%20M%2C,Generalized%20Nakayama%20conjecture%20For)). The *semi-primary rings* mentioned in Bass’s title are precisely finite-dimensional algebras with nilpotent Jacobson radical; the conjecture in this context would imply a strong form of homological regularity for such rings. In summary, the conjecture originated from attempts to classify rings by homological criteria (generalizing the notion of “regular ring” to possibly noncommutative settings) and has been part of the folklore since around 1960.

# Mathematical Analysis

### Definitions and Notation 
- **Projective Dimension ($\mathrm{pd}\,M$):** For a module $M$ over a ring $A$, the projective dimension is the length $n$ of the shortest projective resolution $0 \to P_n \to \cdots \to P_0 \to M \to 0$. If no finite projective resolution exists, $\mathrm{pd}\,M = \infty$. “$M$ has finite projective dimension” means such an $n$ exists (equivalently $\mathrm{pd}\,M < \infty$). 

- **Global Dimension:** The (right) global dimension of $A$ is $\sup\{\mathrm{pd}\,M \mid M \text{ any right $A$-module}\}$. If any module has infinite projective dimension, the global dimension is infinite. For example, a ring is *hereditary* if global dimension $\le 1$, and *regular* (in the commutative sense) if global dimension equals the Krull dimension of the ring ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=Around%20the%20middle%20of%20this,modules)).

- **Finitistic Dimension:** There are two closely related invariants. The *big finitistic dimension* $\operatorname{Fin.dim}A$ is the supremum of $\mathrm{pd}\,M$ over **all** modules $M$ that have finite projective dimension. The *little finitistic dimension* $\operatorname{fin.dim}A$ is the supremum of $\mathrm{pd}\,M$ over all **finitely generated** (or equivalently finite-length) modules $M$ with finite projective dimension ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=variety,formulated%20for%20a%20finite%20dimensional)). For finite-dimensional algebras (Artin algebras), one usually considers finitely generated modules, so $\operatorname{fin.dim}A$ is the relevant quantity. The conjecture can thus be stated as: **For every finite-dimensional $k$-algebra $A$, $\operatorname{fin.dim}A < \infty$.** The user’s statement is equivalent to this, since if $d = \operatorname{fin.dim}A$ is finite, it means every module $M$ with finite $\mathrm{pd}$ satisfies $\mathrm{pd}\,M \le d$. Note that if *no* non-projective module has finite projective dimension (a pathological case), the statement holds trivially with $d=0$ or 1. Usually, however, there do exist some finite-dimensional modules of finite projective dimension, and the conjecture asserts a uniform upper bound on their resolution lengths.

- **Connections to Other Notions:** If $A$ has *finite global dimension*, then obviously $\operatorname{fin.dim}A$ is finite (in fact $\operatorname{fin.dim}A = \mathrm{gldim}\,A$ in that case). Finite global dimension is a very strong condition – for commutative algebras it characterizes regular rings. The finitistic dimension conjecture asks something much weaker: even if $A$ is far from regular (perhaps $\mathrm{gldim}\,A = \infty$), do the “nice” modules (those that *do* happen to have finite resolutions) collectively have a longest resolution length? In commutative algebra, this turned out to be true: Bass proved that for a Noetherian ring, the supremum of finite projective dimensions is actually equal to the Krull dimension ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=the%20projective%20dimension%20of%20M%2C,Generalized%20Nakayama%20conjecture%20For)). In particular, commutative Noetherian rings always have finite finitistic dimension (either it equals the Krull dimension, or in the regular case the fin.dim is actually realized by a maximal Cohen–Macaulay module and equals the ring’s dimension). The conjecture is thus a direct generalization of this fact to *noncommutative* algebras, especially Artin algebras. It is also related to group cohomology: for group algebras $kG$, finite projective dimension modules correspond to groups of finite cohomological dimension. The conjecture holding for $kG$ (with $G$ finite) is true, since $\mathrm{gldim}\,kG < \infty$ in that case, but for general (infinite) groups it connects with questions in group theory. However, the classical formulation restricts to finite-dimensional algebras (Artin algebras), since without finiteness conditions counterexamples can be found (even certain commutative non-Noetherian or infinitely generated algebras can have infinite finitistic dimension).

- **Relationship to Other Conjectures:** The finitistic dimension conjecture is the most general (and believed to be the hardest) in a family of homological conjectures for Artin algebras ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=situation%20there%20are%20conjectures%20which,most%20general%20one%2C%20and%20it)). For instance, it implies the **Nunke Condition** and the **Generalized Nakayama Conjecture** as special cases ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=k,Furthermore)). (Roughly, Nunke’s condition and Nakayama’s conjectures predict existence of non-zero Ext in high degrees for certain module pairs, which would follow if fin.dim$A$ is finite for all algebras ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=k,Furthermore)).) In fact, the conjectures are known to be logically linked: a proof of finitistic dimension finiteness would settle those others. Historically, a “First Finitistic Dimension Conjecture” was also posed, asking whether $\operatorname{Fin.dim}A = \operatorname{fin.dim}A$ for all Artin algebras (i.e. whether allowing infinitely generated modules changes the supremum). **This stronger conjecture was disproven**: there are examples where infinitely generated modules have larger projective dimensions than any finite module. In 1992, Zimmermann-Huisgen demonstrated a “homological domino effect” yielding an infinite strictly increasing chain of projective dimensions ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=rings%2C%20Notes%20by%20Claus%20Michael,383)). Later, S.O. **Smalø** (1998) constructed Artin algebras for which $\operatorname{fin.dim}A$ is finite (say = $n$) but $\operatorname{Fin.dim}A$ is infinite ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=,2622)). In these examples, every finite-length module has projective dimension $\le n$, yet there exist some bizarre, infinitely generated modules with projective dimension beyond $n$ (in fact unbounded). Thus $\operatorname{Fin.dim}A \neq \operatorname{fin.dim}A$ in those cases, refuting the “(a)” version of the conjectures ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=situation%20there%20are%20conjectures%20which,module%20M%20there%20exists)). Fortunately, this does not contradict the standard conjecture (b), which only concerns the finiteness of $\operatorname{fin.dim}A$ itself. In all known examples, whenever $\operatorname{fin.dim}A$ has been computed it turned out finite; no algebra is known where $\operatorname{fin.dim}A = \infty$. The conjecture therefore survives in its “little” form. 

### Known Results and Partial Proofs 
Over the years, many special cases of the finitistic dimension conjecture have been established. Researchers have identified classes of algebras for which $\operatorname{fin.dim}A$ can be proven to be finite, often by finding an explicit uniform projective resolution length or by reducing to simpler algebras. Here are some key positive results:

- **Monomial Algebras:** An important breakthrough came in the late 1980s when the conjecture was proved for *monomial algebras*. A monomial algebra is a quotient of a path algebra $kQ$ by an ideal generated by monomials (paths) in the quiver $Q$. In 1991, Green, Kirkman, and Kuzmanovich showed that if $A$ is a finite-dimensional monomial algebra, then indeed $\operatorname{fin.dim}A$ is finite ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=conjecture%20was%20proved%20for%20monomial,pairs%27%27%20given%20by%20certain%20maps)) ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=,50)). They did this by constructing minimal projective resolutions for simple $A$-modules and observing a uniform bound on their lengths. Essentially, the combinatorial structure of monomial relations allows one to compute resolutions explicitly (often using Gröbner basis techniques and combinatorial “periodicity” in the resolution). Independently, Igusa and Zacharia (1990) gave another proof for monomial algebras ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=conjecture%20was%20proved%20for%20monomial,pairs%27%27%20given%20by%20certain%20maps)) by introducing the concept of *syzygy pairs*, which captured cancellations in the resolution and again led to a uniform projective dimension bound. These results were a strong piece of evidence in favor of the conjecture, covering a broad class of (often wild) algebras.

- **Radical Cube Zero Algebras:** Shortly thereafter, attention turned to algebras with restrictions on powers of the Jacobson radical $J$. Green and Zimmermann-Huisgen (1991) proved that if $A$ has **radical cube zero** ($J^3=0$), then $\operatorname{fin.dim}A < \infty$ ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=holds%20for%20algebras%20with%20radical,conjecture%2C%20which%20we%20here%20call)). Intuitively, $J^3=0$ means any composition of three non-invertible maps (arrows in the quiver) is zero, which simplifies the projective resolutions considerably. In fact, they established an explicit bound in this case. This result was later re-proved and generalized by Igusa and Todorov, and by others, using different methods. The generalization extended to algebras where higher powers of the radical vanish *and* the factor algebra by a lower power has finite representation type. For example, Draxler and Happel (1992) showed the conjecture holds if $J^{2\ell+1}=0$ and $A/J^{\ell}$ is of finite representation type ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=holds%20for%20algebras%20with%20radical,conjecture%2C%20which%20we%20here%20call)). Finite representation type (having only finitely many indecomposable modules up to isomorphism) often forces homological dimensions to be tame. In these scenarios, one can often reduce the problem to analyzing a finite (sometimes hereditary) subalgebra. Collectively, these results cover many “small” algebras (e.g. all algebras with Loewy length $\le 3$ are settled). 

- **Special Classes and Reductions:** Numerous other classes have been verified. For example, the conjecture is trivially true for *hereditary* algebras (global dimension $\le 1$) and for *Nakayama algebras* (which have well-understood resolutions). It is known to hold for **triangular matrix algebras** (an algebra of the form $\begin{pmatrix} B & M \\ 0 & C \end{pmatrix}$ has fin.dim bounded by the sum of fin.dim$B$ and fin.dim$C$, under certain conditions). **Rep\-resentation-finite** algebras, and more generally algebras of *low representation dimension*, also satisfy the conjecture. (Auslander’s notion of **representation dimension** measures how far an algebra is from being of finite representation type. Results by Igusa-Todorov and others have shown that if an algebra’s representation dimension is $\le 3$, it implies fin.dim is finite – essentially because such algebras admit a special “generator” whose endomorphism algebra has finite global dimension ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0001870809002187#:~:text=References%201.%20,Representation%20Dimension%20of%20Artin%20Algebras)).) Moreover, in recent years the conjecture has been proven for some *extension and localization* classes: for instance, if an algebra can be obtained as a fairly “nice” extension of another known algebra, finiteness is preserved ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0022404916301293#:~:text=The%20finitistic%20dimension%20conjecture%20asserts,If%20the%20extension%20is%20right)). A 2015 result by Wang and Xi reduced the general conjecture to a statement about *radical-power extensions*: roughly, it suffices to prove fin.dim is finite for certain extended algebras built from simpler ones ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0022404916301293#:~:text=The%20finitistic%20dimension%20conjecture%20asserts,If%20the%20extension%20is%20right)). This means any hypothetical counterexample would have to survive these reduction steps, becoming a minimal counterexample in some category of extensions – a strategy that so far has found no counterexample.

- **No Known Counterexamples:** Crucially, despite extensive computational searches and theoretical efforts, **no counterexample to the conjecture (b)** is known. Every finite-dimensional algebra studied either has been proved to have finite finitistic dimension or remains elusive. In particular, many experts believe the conjecture is true, and work has focused on developing tools to eventually prove it in general (or at least explain why known methods haven’t found a counterexample). The absence of counterexamples even in computer-generated random algebras or in extreme cases (e.g. algebras of high wild representation type) is a positive sign. However, the problem is subtle: it’s not enough for each *individual* module’s projective dimension to be finite – that is usually true – one needs a uniform bound across all finite modules. Counterexamples to the stronger conjecture (big = little) show that wild behavior can occur with infinitely generated modules, but finite modules thus far seem to obey a uniform bound in practice. 

### Critical Example: Big vs. Little Finitistic Dimension Gap  
While no algebra is known with truly infinite finitic dimension, it’s instructive to see *how* the stronger version fails. We outline Smalø’s 1998 example in broad strokes (without technical details): He constructed a family of artinian algebras $A$ (of quiver type) such that $\operatorname{fin.dim}A$ is very small (often 3 or another fixed small integer), yet for each $N>0$ there exists some (infinite-dimensional) $A$-module $M_N$ with $\mathrm{pd}\,M_N > N$ ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=,2622)). The construction uses a clever “layering” of projective modules to force longer and longer resolutions for specially tailored modules. Intuitively, one starts with an algebra that has $\operatorname{fin.dim}=3$ (for example) and then creates a sequence of larger and larger modules by pasting together pieces so that each new module’s resolution requires one more step than the previous. These $M_N$ modules are not finitely generated (they are infinite direct sums of finite modules carefully arranged), so they do not violate the little conjecture. But they demonstrate that no single finite $d$ can bound *all* modules’ projective dimensions if we allow infinite length modules. Thus $\operatorname{Fin.dim}A$ can be infinite even when $\operatorname{fin.dim}A$ stays finite. Birge Zimmermann-Huisgen’s earlier work (1992) provided a conceptual framework for this “infinite escalation” – termed a *homological domino effect* ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=rings%2C%20Notes%20by%20Claus%20Michael,383)) – showing how the failure in one degree forces failures in higher degrees for larger and larger modules. This kind of example underscores *why* the conjecture restricts to finite-dimensional modules: without that restriction the statement is false in a dramatic way. It also highlights the difficulty of the problem – even controlling the homological behavior of finite modules is quite non-trivial and requires global techniques.

# Techniques and Methodologies
Researchers have developed a variety of tools to attack the finitistic dimension conjecture. Because the problem spans module theory, homological algebra, and even category theory, the approaches are diverse. Below we survey some of the key techniques and ideas that have been employed:

- **Explicit Resolution Construction:** Much progress has come from *constructing minimal projective resolutions* for classes of modules. For “nice” algebras (monomial algebras, radical-power-zero algebras, etc.), one can often describe the projective resolution of a simple module in combinatorial terms ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=conjecture%20was%20proved%20for%20monomial,pairs%27%27%20given%20by%20certain%20maps)). For example, in monomial algebras each projective covers a basis of paths, and the differentials in a resolution can be written down using overlaps of monomial relations. By analyzing these differentials, Green–Kirkman–Kuzmanovich were able to bound the length of any resolution ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=conjecture%20was%20proved%20for%20monomial,pairs%27%27%20given%20by%20certain%20maps)). Tools like *Gröbner bases* for path algebras and *Anick’s resolution* (a combinatorial resolution for algebras given by generators and relations) have been invaluable. This explicit approach is very concrete but can get complicated as the algebra’s relations get more involved. Still, it has yielded results for special cases and provides intuition: the conjecture holds in situations where one can “see” a pattern in all resolutions that forces termination by a fixed length.

- **Syzygy and Homological Invariants:** In their work on monomial algebras, Igusa and Zacharia introduced **syzygy pairs**, a technique to study properties of successive syzygies (kernels of differentials in the resolution) ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=conjecture%20was%20proved%20for%20monomial,pairs%27%27%20given%20by%20certain%20maps)). By categorizing how these syzygies behave and pairing them up via certain homomorphisms, they could prevent an unbounded growth of projective dimensions. Building on this, Igusa and Todorov later developed new **homological invariants**, such as the $\phi$-*dimension*, intended to measure the “complexity” of a module category. The $\phi$-dimension (Igusa–Todorov, 2005) gives an upper bound on $\operatorname{fin.dim}A$. They conjectured that in fact $\phi\text{-dim}(A) = \operatorname{fin.dim}A$, which would have solved the conjecture if true. However, a recent result by Hanson and Igusa (2019) produced a counterexample to the *$\phi$-dimension conjecture* ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.00614#:~:text=2019,an%20Artin%20algebra%2C%20now%20known)), showing that $\phi$-dimension can be strictly smaller than the actual finitistic dimension in some cases. Despite this setback, the introduction of such invariants has been fruitful – they provide new quantitative tools and often simplify proofs of known finiteness results. For example, Igusa–Todorov invariants are used to give elegant proofs that $\operatorname{fin.dim}A$ is finite for radical^{3}=0 algebras and other special types, by showing $\phi$-dim is finite there.

- **Lifting to Derived Categories:** A striking approach by Jeremy **Rickard** (2018) uses *derived category theory*. Rickard considered the question: if the category of $A$-modules has certain nice generation properties, does it force resolutions to terminate? Specifically, he investigated whether the **unbounded derived category** $D^b(A)$ is generated by compact objects (or by the injective modules of $A$) ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=Institutt%20for%20matematiske%20fag%20Summer,parallel%20theories%20of%20cohomology%20were)). In a landmark result, Rickard showed that if one can demonstrate a certain *triangulated category generation property* for $A$ (roughly, that the *injective* modules generate the derived category as a triangulated category), then the finitistic dimension conjecture holds for $A$. This approach connects the problem to deep homological properties of derived categories and has reinvigorated interest via modern homological algebra. While the generation condition is difficult to verify in general, it holds for many known cases and offers a conceptual angle: the conjecture is equivalent to saying “injectives generate the derived category for every Artin algebra” ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=The%20subject%20This%20page%20is,parallel%20theories%20of%20cohomology%20were)). This ties the problem to Auslander–Reiten theory and – interestingly – to *Hochschild cohomology*. In fact, Auslander had formulated a related conjecture (sometimes called the **Auslander conjecture** in this context) which implies the finitistic dimension conjecture ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=holds%20for%20algebras%20with%20radical,i%7D_%7BA%7D%28X%2CY%29)). Auslander conjectured that for any module $X$, if $\Ext^i_A(X,Y)=0$ for all sufficiently large $i$, then in fact $\Ext^i_A(X,Y)=0$ for all $i$ beyond some uniform bound $N$ (depending on $X$). He proved that this statement for the enveloping algebra $A^e$ is equivalent to the finitistic dimension being finite ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=holds%20for%20algebras%20with%20radical,i%7D_%7BA%7D%28X%2CY%29)). Rickard’s work can be seen as operating in a similar spirit but in the derived category language.

- **Reduction Techniques:** A powerful strategy has been to **reduce** the conjecture to “smaller” or “easier” cases. For example, one can attempt to show that if $A$ has a certain complicated structure, it contains or is Morita equivalent to a smaller algebra $B$ for which the conjecture is known. **Idempotent reduction** is one such method: removing an idempotent (which corresponds to cutting down to a full subcategory of representations) can simplify an algebra. A result along these lines by Bravo and Paquette (2019) showed that if $\Lambda$ is an algebra with a simple module $S$ of finite projective dimension, then one can pass to a certain idempotent quotient of $\Lambda$ that “reflects” finiteness of the finitistic dimension ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.00317#:~:text=Title%3A%20Idempotent%20reduction%20for%20the,S%24%20of%20finite%20projective%20dimension)). In plain terms, if part of the algebra is well-behaved (has a finite $\mathrm{pd}$ simple), one can often focus on that part. **Extension and fiber products** of algebras have also been studied: Changchang Xi and others (2015–2018) developed a framework to reduce the conjecture to checking it on extensions where one algebra’s radical fits into another’s structure ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0022404916301293#:~:text=The%20finitistic%20dimension%20conjecture%20asserts,If%20the%20extension%20is%20right)). They proved statements like: if $B \subseteq A$ is an algebra extension such that certain ideals of $B$ are nilpotent in a controlled way, then $\operatorname{fin.dim}A$ is finite provided $\operatorname{fin.dim}B$ is finite ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0022404916301293#:~:text=The%20finitistic%20dimension%20conjecture%20asserts,If%20the%20extension%20is%20right)). This breaks the problem into potentially simpler sub-problems on subalgebras or quotient algebras. Another recent innovation (2025) is the **monomial arrow removal** technique ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.23747#:~:text=2025,bound%20quiver%20algebras%2C%20and%20show)). Erdmann, Solberg, and collaborators introduced operations on the quiver of an algebra that systematically remove certain arrows (and adjust relations) while preserving the finiteness of finitistic dimension. By applying a sequence of such arrow-removals, one can sometimes reduce an arbitrary algebra to a *monomial* or a representation-finite algebra, thereby proving the conjecture for the original by transitively using known cases ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.23747#:~:text=2025,bound%20quiver%20algebras%2C%20and%20show)). These reduction techniques are promising: they aim to show that any would-be counterexample could be peeled away to a simpler core – a core which empirical evidence suggests likely doesn’t exist.

- **Computational and Model-Theoretic Methods:** On another front, some researchers have used computational algebra systems to calculate projective dimensions for random algebras or specific families, searching for patterns or potential counterexamples. So far, these experiments have supported the conjecture by failing to find unbounded behavior in finite modules. Additionally, methods from **model theory** (e.g. the Ziegler spectrum of modules) have been applied. Krause (1998) connected finitistic dimension to properties of the category of *pure-injective* modules ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=emphasis%20on%20fields%2C%20rings%2C%20modules%2C,of%20algebras%20by%20dominant%20dimension)), and others have considered whether infinite length modules that witness large projective dimensions must appear as logical limits of finite ones. While abstract, these approaches can sometimes rephrase the conjecture in terms of the absence of certain types of module-theoretic pathology, possibly making it more tractable with logical tools.

In summary, the attack on the finitistic dimension conjecture is multi-pronged. Some methods (explicit resolutions, syzygy manipulations) tackle the problem head-on by understanding resolutions module by module. Others (derived categories, Auslander’s conjecture) reframe it in a larger context, hoping to leverage deeper structural theorems. And yet others (reduction techniques, computational checks) aim to cut the giant down to size or at least provide evidence of its truth. The diversity of techniques also means that the conjecture has inspired development of several independent theories – each valuable in its own right – such as Igusa–Todorov theory, Auslander–Igusa theory of subcategories, and connections to triangulated category generation. 

# Latest Progress and Outlook
The last few years have seen continued activity. While a complete proof remains elusive, researchers have tightened the net of partial results and drawn surprising connections to other conjectures:

- **Symmetry and Higher Structures:** It has been observed that finiteness of finitistic dimension is related to a symmetry property in homological algebra. Recent work (Ruoyu Guo, 2024) studies a conjectured symmetry of certain *derived invariants* (called “derived delooping levels”) and shows it is closely linked to the finitistic dimension conjecture ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2406.00253#:~:text=2024,extends%20to%20one%20of%20its)). This kind of work suggests that proving FDC might require proving an even more general statement about the structure of derived categories or Ext-algebras, thereby linking it with other famous conjectures (for example, the *Hochschild cohomology symmetry conjecture*).

- **New Reduction Approaches:** In 2023, MacQuarrie and Naves showed that in certain *quotient extensions* $B\subseteq A$ (where $A$ is built from $B$ with additional radical layers), one can relate $\operatorname{fin.dim}A$ to $\operatorname{fin.dim}B$ ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02539#:~:text=2023,algebras%20such%20that%20the%20projective)). Their results continue a theme of “breaking down” the problem: if one proves it for a base algebra $B$, it holds for a larger algebra $A$ constructed in controlled ways from $B$. This incremental approach is narrowing the types of algebras one must ultimately prove the conjecture for.

- **Monomial Techniques Generalized:** The idea of simplifying algebras via arrow removal ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.23747#:~:text=2025,bound%20quiver%20algebras%2C%20and%20show)) (mentioned above) is quite new (2025) and offers a systematic way to reduce to monomial algebras. Since monomial algebras are known to satisfy FDC, this is a promising route. The strategy is to show that any finite-dimensional algebra can be transformed, through a finite sequence of “monomial mutations,” into a monomial algebra without introducing infinite $\mathrm{pd}$ in the process. Early results show this works for certain classes of quivers. If it can be fully generalized, it would essentially solve the conjecture by reduction. 

- **Exploring Specific Algebra Families:** Researchers are also homing in on specific families of potential counterexamples. One focus has been on **quotient of polynomial algebras** (or quiver algebras) by *quadratic relations*. These are algebras defined by homogeneous relations of degree 2. Such algebras include *Koszul algebras* and others that are better understood. A question asked on MathOverflow was whether *quadratic algebras* could violate FDC – preliminary evidence suggests they do not, and many have finite finitistic dimension due to their grading and Koszul properties. Another family under scrutiny is **group algebras** of infinite groups: while group algebras are not artinian unless the group is finite, one can consider artinian quotients or blocks. No issues have been found here either, aligning with known group cohomology patterns.

- **Connections to $K$-theory and Others:** Interestingly, the conjecture has even made appearances in adjacent fields. Some results in algebraic $K$-theory (relating to the vanishing of higher Hochschild homology) assume finiteness of finitistic dimension as a condition. This cross-pollination means progress on FDC could impact results in algebraic geometry and topology that use homological dimensions as hypotheses.

**Outlook:** As of the current date, the finitistic dimension conjecture remains open, but optimism persists. The steady accumulation of positive results in special cases, and the failure to find any counterexample, suggest that a proof (or a very deep counterexample) might emerge in the coming years. The problem has already led to rich developments in representation theory and homological algebra. Even if the conjecture were somehow false, the structure of a counterexample would itself be extremely enlightening (it would likely be a very wild algebra with exotic module behavior). In the more expected event that the conjecture is true, the proof will likely synthesize many of the techniques mentioned – combining explicit module-theoretic control with higher-level categorical reasoning. In any case, the pursuit of this conjecture continues to be a driving force in modern algebra, inspiring new ideas and connecting disparate areas of mathematics.
