Bass proved fundamental results in the commutative case (showing the finiteness of finitistic dimension for Noetherian rings, relating it to Krull dimension ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=the%20projective%20dimension%20of%20M%2C,Generalized%20Nakayama%20conjecture%20For))) and raised the question for general Artinian rings. It set the stage for all subsequent work on the conjecture.

2. **Birge Zimmermann-Huisgen (1992).** *“Homological domino effects and the first finitistic dimension conjecture,”* **Invent. Math. 108** (1992), 369–383. ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=rings%2C%20Notes%20by%20Claus%20Michael,383)) **Annotation:** A seminal work that investigates the mechanism by which finite projective dimensions can propagate to larger and larger modules (*domino effects*). Zimmermann-Huisgen provided deep insight into why the *big* finitistic dimension can differ from the little one, constructing chains of modules with increasing $\mathrm{pd}$. Her methods introduced new techniques to produce or prevent unbounded resolutions, influencing much later research.

3. **E. L. Green, E. Kirkman, J. Kuzmanovich (1991).** *“Finitistic dimensions of finite-dimensional monomial algebras,”* **J. Algebra 136** (1991), 37–50. ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=conjecture%20was%20proved%20for%20monomial,pairs%27%27%20given%20by%20certain%20maps)) ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=,50)) **Annotation:** This paper proved the conjecture for monomial algebras, a broad class with combinatorial structure. The authors explicitly constructed projective resolutions for simple modules using combinatorial data from the quiver and relations, and they derived a uniform bound on resolution lengths. The result was one of the first general proofs of FDC for a non-trivial family of wild algebras, lending credence to the conjecture’s truth.

4. **Jeremy Rickard (2019).** *“Unbounded derived categories and the finitistic dimension conjecture,”* **Adv. Math. 354** (2019), 106735 (21 pages). ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=Institutt%20for%20matematiske%20fag%20Summer,parallel%20theories%20of%20cohomology%20were)) **Annotation:** In this modern approach, Rickard reframes the finitistic dimension conjecture in terms of derived categories and triangulated generation. He shows that finiteness of fin.dim is equivalent to a certain generation condition in the unbounded derived category of $A$. This paper opened a new avenue of attack by linking the conjecture to big structures in homological algebra, and it has inspired further work on derived invariants related to FDC.

5. **Chengxi Wang and Changchang Xi (2017).** *“Finitistic dimension conjecture and radical-power extensions,”* **J. Pure Appl. Algebra 221** (2017), 832–846. ([www.sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0022404916301293#:~:text=The%20finitistic%20dimension%20conjecture%20asserts,If%20the%20extension%20is%20right)) **Annotation:** This is one of a series of papers by Xi and collaborators aimed at reducing the general conjecture to more manageable subproblems. In this work, they show that if one can solve the conjecture for certain extension algebras (where one algebra’s radical-power ideal sits in another algebra), then one obtains a solution for all algebras. Essentially, they prove the conjecture is “reduction closed” under a class of extensions, thereby significantly narrowing the search for a proof. This paper exemplifies the use of induction and reduction techniques that have become central in recent progress.

6. **S. O. Smalø (1998).** *“The supremum of the difference between the big and little finitistic dimensions is infinite,”* **Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 126** (1998), 2619–2622. ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=,2622)) **Annotation:** A short but impactful paper, Smalø constructs examples of Artin algebras that separate the big and little finitistic dimensions as much as desired. This provided a clear refutation of the earlier “first” finitistic dimension conjecture and highlighted the subtlety of the “little” conjecture. Smalø’s construction techniques (based on clever module constructions) have informed how algebraists think about potential extremal behavior in homological dimensions.

7. **Birge Huisgen-Zimmermann & Søren O. Smalø (1991).** *“Finitistic dimension of Artinian rings with vanishing radical cube,”* **Math. Z. 206** (1991), 505–526. ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=finite,526)) **Annotation:** In this paper (often cited as Green–Zimmermann, 1991, since the first author E. Green’s contributions are incorporated in related work), the authors prove FDC for the class of algebras with $J^3=0$. They develop techniques to handle algebras with small radical lengths, using both combinatorial and Homological algebra arguments. This result was a significant step beyond the monomial case and introduced methods (like “parallel splitting” of projectives) that proved useful in later generalizations.

8. **Kiyoshi Igusa & Gordana Todorov (2005).** *“On the finitistic global dimension conjecture for Artin algebras,”* unpublished preprint, 2005; see also later works culminating in Eric Hanson & K. Igusa (2019) ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.00614#:~:text=2019,an%20Artin%20algebra%2C%20now%20known)). **Annotation:** Igusa and Todorov’s series of works (mid-2000s) introduced the $\phi$-dimension and related invariants, developing an influential framework now called *Igusa-Todorov theory*. While the 2005 preprint itself remained unpublished, its ideas were disseminated in conferences and later papers. The approach provided new upper bounds for $\operatorname{fin.dim}A$ and showed that many algebras have fin.dim bounded by functions of more accessible invariants. The culmination was the *$\phi$-dimension conjecture* (that $\phi$-dim = fin.dim), which was disproven in 2019 ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.00614#:~:text=2019,an%20Artin%20algebra%2C%20now%20known)). Nonetheless, the techniques (e.g. the Igusa-Todorov function, and the concept of “IT-algebras”) continue to be key tools in current research on the conjecture.

9. **Øyvind Solberg (2001, ed.).** *“Homological Conjectures for Finite Dimensional Algebras – Summer School Lecture Notes,”* NTNU, 2001. ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=variety,k%29%20is%20the%20usual)) ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=The%20little%20finitistic%20dimension%20being,the%20Nunke%20condition%2C%20which%20in)) **Annotation:** These are lecture notes from a summer school that surveyed the status of various homological conjectures (including FDC) as of 2001. They provide a comprehensive overview of known implications between conjectures, partial results, and techniques (with an extensive bibliography) ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=situation%20there%20are%20conjectures%20which,most%20general%20one%2C%20and%20it)) ([oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no](https://oyvinso.folk.ntnu.no/Nordfjordeid/History/homconjsubject.html#:~:text=The%20little%20finitistic%20dimension%20being,the%20Nunke%20condition%2C%20which%20in)). While not a research paper per se, this reference is invaluable for historical context and as a roadmap to the literature up to that point. It’s often cited for background and for the clear exposition of how FDC relates to other conjectures like Nunke’s condition and Nakayama’s conjecture.

10. **Karin Erdmann, Odysseas Giatagantzidis, Chrysostomos Psaroudakis, Øyvind Solberg (2025).** *“Monomial arrow removal and the finitistic dimension conjecture,”* preprint (arXiv 2025). ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.23747#:~:text=2025,bound%20quiver%20algebras%2C%20and%20show)) **Annotation:** A very recent paper that introduces a novel technique to simplify algebras while preserving finitistic dimension properties. By systematically removing arrows from quivers and adjusting relations (whenever an arrow is proven “redundant” for homological purposes), the authors reduce algebras to monomial ones. This paper is on the cutting edge of current research; its methods have the potential to settle new cases of the conjecture or even lead to a general proof. It also showcases the continued relevance of combinatorial methods in tackling this deep homological problem.
